title:
Spectral analysis of Dirac operators for dislocated potentials with a
  purely imaginary jump

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper we present a complete spectral analysis of Dirac operators with non-Hermitian matrix potentials of the form $\imath \operatorname{sgn}(x)+V(x)$ where $V \in L^{1}$. For $V=0$ we compute explicitly the matrix Green function. This allows us to determine the spectrum, which is purely essential, and its different types. It also allows us to find sharp enclosures for the pseudospectrum and its complement, in all parts of the complex plane. Notably, this includes the instability region, corresponding to the interior of the band that forms the numerical range. Then, with the help of a Birman-Schwinger principle, we establish in precise manner how the spectrum and pseudospectrum change when $V \neq 0$, assuming the hypotheses $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<1$ or $V \in L^{1} \cap L^{p}$ where $p>1$. We show that the essential spectra remain unchanged and that the $\varepsilon$-pseudospectrum stays close to the instability region for small $\varepsilon$. We determine sharp asymptotics for the discrete spectrum, whenever $V$ satisfies further conditions of decay at infinity. Finally, in one of our main findings, we give a complete description of the weakly-coupled model.

# 1. InTRODUCTION 

1.1. Context and motivations. The significance of the Dirac equation lies on the fact that it describes, not only relativistic particles in quantum mechanics, but also advanced materials such as graphene. Mathematically, the study of this equation is notoriously difficult, partly because of the spinorial structure of the underlying Hilbert space and partly because of the lack of semi-boundedness and positivity-preserving properties. In this respect, the spectral analysis of the underlying matrix differential operator is considerably more challenging than that of its non-relativistic counterpart, the scalar Schrödinger operator.

Recently, we have seen unprecedented interest in the study of non-selfadjoint electromagnetic perturbations of the Dirac equation $[8,6,7,9,4,19,14,10,11,24,16,18]$. This is justified, on the one hand, by the availability of new proper connections with quantum mechanics [26, 22], and, on the other hand, by the new conceptual paradigms posed by the notions of pseudospectra of linear operators.

This paper is motivated by the current lack of understanding of the structure of the pseudospectra of non-selfadjoint Dirac operators. Indeed, the only available work in this direction seems to be the recent non-semiclassical construction of pseudomodes given in [19].

In order to provide an insight into the pseudospectral properties of the Dirac equation in general, and at the same time set a benchmark that differs from the available scalar models given by the classical nonselfadjoint Schrödinger operator, the present paper is devoted to introducing and examining in close detail the non-selfadjoint Dirac operator,

$$
\mathscr{L}_{m, V}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
m & -\partial_{x} \\
\partial_{x} & -m
\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{cc}
i \operatorname{sgn}(x) & 0 \\
0 & i \operatorname{sgn}(x)
\end{array}\right)+V(x)
$$

on a suitable domain of $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ where $V: \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}$ is a long-range possibly non-Hermitian matrix potential. The unperturbed operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}=\mathscr{L}_{m, 0}$ is a relativistic non-selfadjoint version of the quantum mechanical infinite square well.

The choice is motivated by the scalar Schrödinger case on $L^{2}(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C})$ considered in [15],

$$
-\partial_{x}^{2}+i \operatorname{sgn}(x)
$$

with potential perturbations, and it serves as a link with the analysis conducted in [8]. The scalar model (1.2) was instrumental for the non-semiclassical construction of pseudomodes established in [21], which eventually solved a notorious open problem raised during a workshop at the American Institute of Mathematics in 2015, cf. [1, Open Problem 10.1]. The relativistic variant of this construction has now been reported in [19].

The simplicity of the linear operator (1.2) is deceiving, as it hides a non-trivial structure on its pseudospectrum. Our findings reveal two main distinctions between (1.1) and this scalar model. One is about this structure and one is about the available tools to analyse it. The latter is to be expected, given the higher degree of complexity of a matrix versus a scalar operator. But the former is rather surprising. As we shall see in the next section, the linear operator (1.1) has a resolvent norm that grows quadratically, rather than linearly, at infinity inside the band forming the spectral instability region.
1.2. Structure of the paper. The organisation of the paper is as follows. Section 2 is devoted to a proper mathematical description of our main contributions. The body of the paper is Sections 3-5, where we establish the proofs of these results. After this, Appendix A includes complete details of the Birman-Schwinger-type principle formulated in [13] which is crucial to our analysis.

The core Sections $3-5$ consist of two parts.

- The unperturbed operator, comprising Sections 3 and 4. We begin our study of (1.1) in Section 3 by finding the explicit expression of the matrix Green function of the unperturbed operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. This allows to determine the spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. As it turns out, the latter is purely essential and it comprises four symmetric segments on the boundary of the band $\Sigma=\{|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\}$ for $m>0$, while by contrast it is equal to $\bar{\Sigma}$ for $m=0$. In Section 4 we find enclosures for the pseudospectrum and its complement, in all parts of the complex plane. In one of our main contributions, we compute the explicit asymptotic constants, up to order 0 , of the resolvent norm of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ inside the instability region $\Sigma$. The latter coincides with the interior of the numerical range.
- Perturbations, comprising Section 5. The second part of the paper is devoted to the case $V \neq 0$. By applying a non-selfadjoint version of the classical Birman-Schwinger principle, we establish in precise manner how spectrum and pseudospectrum change, under two general hypotheses, $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<$ 1 or $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right) \cap L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ for some $p>1$. We show that the essential spectra remain unchanged in both cases and that the $\varepsilon$-pseudospectrum stays close to the instability region for small $\varepsilon>0$ whenever $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<1$. Then, we formulate our two other main contributions of this part. On the one hand, we determine sharp asymptotics for the discrete spectrum, whenever $V$

satisfies further conditions of decay at infinity. On the other hand, we give a complete description of the weakly-coupled model, corresponding to potential $\epsilon V$ in the regime $\epsilon \rightarrow 0$.
1.3. Notation used throughout the work. The following specific conventions will be used throughout this paper.

- $\mathbb{R}_{+}=[0,+\infty)$ and $\mathbb{R}_{-}=(-\infty, 0]$.
- $[[m, n]]=\{k \in \mathbb{N}: m \leq k \leq n\}$ for $m, n \in \mathbb{R}$.
- For a closed operator $\mathscr{L}: \operatorname{Dom}(\mathscr{L}) \longrightarrow \mathcal{H}$, the spectrum is denoted by

$$
\operatorname{Spec}(\mathscr{L})=\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}(\mathscr{L}) \cup \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{r}}(\mathscr{L}) \cup \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathscr{L})
$$

where the point, residual and continuous spectrum denote, as usual,
$\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}(\mathscr{L})=\{z \in \mathbb{C}: \mathscr{L}-z$ is not injective $\}$
$\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{r}}(\mathscr{L})=\{z \in \mathbb{C}: \mathscr{L}-z$ is injective and $\overline{\operatorname{Ran}(\mathscr{L}-z)} \subsetneq \mathcal{H}\}$,
$\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{c}}(\mathscr{L})=\{z \in \mathbb{C}: \mathscr{L}-z$ is injective and $\overline{\operatorname{Ran}(\mathscr{L}-z)}=\mathcal{H}$ and $\operatorname{Ran}(\mathscr{L}-z) \subsetneq \mathcal{H}\}$.
The resolvent set is denoted by $\rho(\mathscr{L})$.

- We use the classical definitions of the five types of essential spectrum, [12, Sec. IX] or [20, Sec. 5.4]. We write $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} j}(\mathscr{L})$ for $\mathrm{j} \in[[1,5]]$, where $\mathscr{L}-z$
- is not semi-Fredholm for e1,
- possess a singular Weyl sequence for e2,
- is not Fredholm for e3,
- is not Fredholm of index 0 for e4,
- is such that either $z \in \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 1}(\mathscr{L})$ or the resolvent set does not intersect the connected component of the complement of $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 1}(\mathscr{L})$ where $z$ lies, for e5.
- The discrete spectrum is denoted as

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{dis}}(\mathscr{L})=\mathbb{C} \backslash \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 5}(\mathscr{L})
$$

and it is the set of isolated eigenvalues such that the Riesz projector has a finite-dimensional range.

- For $\varepsilon>0$, the $\varepsilon$-pseudospectrum is denoted by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Spec}_{\varepsilon}(\mathscr{L}) & =\operatorname{Spec}(\mathscr{L}) \cup\left\{z \in \rho(\mathscr{L}):\left\|(\mathscr{L}-z)^{-1}\right\|>\varepsilon^{-1}\right\} \\
& =\bigcup_{\|V\| \leq \varepsilon} \operatorname{Spec}(\mathscr{L}+V)
\end{aligned}
$$

By convention, we set $\operatorname{Spec}_{0}(\mathscr{L})=\operatorname{Spec}(\mathscr{L})$.

- $\left|\cdot\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}$ is the Euclidean norm for vectors.
- $\left|\cdot\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}$ is the operator norm induced by $|\cdot|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}$ for matrices.
- $|\cdot|_{\mathrm{F}}$ is the Frobenius norm for matrices.
- For a measurable matrix-valued function $V: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}$, we write $V \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ for $p \in[1, \infty]$ to indicate that $|V|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \in L^{p}(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C})$. We denote the $L^{p}$ norm of $V$ by

$$
\|V\|_{L^{p}}=\left\|\left|V\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\right\|_{L^{p}}
$$

- For a positive function $\nu^{\prime}(x)$, we define the measure $\mathrm{d} \nu(x)=\nu^{\prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x$. We say that $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} ; \mathrm{d} \nu\right)$ if

$$
\|V\|_{L^{1}(\mathrm{~d} \nu)}=\int_{\mathbb{R}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \nu^{\prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x<\infty
$$

2. Mathematical framework and summary of results

Below, we set

$$
S_{m}= \begin{cases}\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m,|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\}, & \text { if } m>0 \\ \{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1\}, & \text { if } m=0\end{cases}
$$

and we write $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)=L^{2}(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}) \oplus L^{2}(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C})$ with the inner product

$$
\langle f, g\rangle=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f_{1}(x) \overline{g_{1}(x)}+f_{2}(x) \overline{g_{2}(x)} \mathrm{d} x \quad \text { for components } f_{j}, g_{j} \in L^{2}(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C})
$$

As usual,

$$
\sigma_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
0 & 1 \\
1 & 0
\end{array}\right), \quad \sigma_{2}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & -i \\
i & 0
\end{array}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \sigma_{3}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & -1
\end{array}\right)
$$

denote the Pauli matrices. For mass $m \geq 0$, let $\mathcal{D}_{m}: H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \longrightarrow L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ be the one-dimensional free particle Dirac operator, given by

$$
\left(\mathcal{D}_{m} f\right)(x)=\left(-i \partial_{x}\right) \sigma_{2} f(x)+m \sigma_{3} f(x)
$$

It is well-known that $\mathcal{D}_{m}$ is a selfadjoint linear operator and that its spectrum is

$$
\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathcal{D}_{m}\right)=(-\infty,-m] \cup[m,+\infty)
$$

Moreover, $\mathcal{D}_{m}$ is unitarily equivalent to the selfadjoint operator $\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{m}=\left(-i \partial_{x}\right) \sigma_{1}+m \sigma_{3}: H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \longrightarrow$ $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ via transformation by $\left(\begin{array}{cc}i & 0 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\right)$. This other realisation of the free particle Dirac operator is the one considered in $[8,9,19]$. In the present paper we prefer the formulation (2.2), noting that the results we report below, map in a straightforward manner onto $\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{m}$.
2.1. The Dirac operator with a dislocation. In the present paper we examine the linear operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}: H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \longrightarrow L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ given by

$$
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m} f\right)(x)=\mathcal{D}_{m} f(x)+i \operatorname{sgn}(x) f(x)
$$

and its perturbations by a potential. Since multiplication by $i \operatorname{sgn}(x) I$ is a bounded operator, $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is also closed. From the explicit expression of the adjoint,

$$
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}^{*} f\right)(x)=\mathcal{D}_{m} f(x)-i \operatorname{sgn}(x) f(x)
$$

it follows that $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is not a normal operator. As we shall see below, the spectral and pseudospectral properties of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ and its perturbations, are rather unusual and very interesting.

The numerical range of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is the infinite closed strip

$$
\operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\mathbb{R}+i[-1,1]
$$

See Figure 1 and the beginning of Section 3. Unlike the Schrödinger operator with dislocated potential analysed in [15], $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is neither sectorial nor $\mathcal{P} \mathcal{T}$-symmetric. However, $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is $\mathcal{T}$-selfadjoint and this implies that the spectrum respects some of the symmetries that the Schrödinger model possesses.
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1. The numerical range of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$.

Here and everywhere below a distinction of the case $m=0$, is evident, unavoidable and it is typical of families of non-selfadjoint operators dependent on a parameter, $c f$. the examples in [2] and references therein. Moreover, setting an unitary operator $S f=g$ such that $g(x)=a f\left(a^{2} x\right)$ for fixed non-zero $a \in \mathbb{R} \cup i \mathbb{R}$, it is readily seen that $S$ preserves the domains and

$$
\left(S^{*} \mathscr{L}_{a^{2} m} S f\right)(x)=a^{2}\left(\mathcal{D}_{m} f(x)+\frac{i}{a^{2}} \operatorname{sgn}\left(\frac{x}{a^{2}}\right) f(x)\right)
$$

This shows that both the case $m<0$ and the case of a dislocated potential of the form $c \operatorname{sgn}(x) I$, where $c>0$ is a constant, are covered by our results below.

As we shall see in Section 3, the spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ can be determined analytically using arguments based on resolvent construction and Weyl sequences. For all $m>0$, the spectrum is purely continuous

$$
\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}_{c}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=S_{m}
$$

Furthermore, all essential spectra coincide,

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right), \quad \forall \mathrm{j} \in[[1,5]]
$$

Note that $\mathcal{T}$-selfadjointness implies equality of the essential spectra for $\mathrm{j} \in[[1,4]]$ only, so the proof of equality of the full set requires extra arguments given below. An illustration of the spectrum is included in Figure 2.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2. The red lines represent the spectrum of the operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ when $m>0$.
In contrast, for $m=0$, the spectrum is characterized by

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\} \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{c}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\}
$$

Unlike the case $m>0$, the essential spectra are not identical:

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\}, \quad \forall \mathrm{j} \in[[1,4]] \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 5}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)
$$

See the illustration in Figure 3.
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3. The red lines show the continuous spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{0}$. These lines coincide with the essential spectra e1,.., e4. The inner part in light colour shows the point spectrum. The union of both these regions form the essential spectrum e5 and also the full $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)$.

For all $m \geq 0$, the comparison with the spectrum of $\mathcal{D}_{m}$ is obvious and striking. Despite the seemingly simple structure of the dislocation $i \operatorname{sgn}(x) I$, the perturbation splits the spectrum into two halves. In the case $m>0$, this phenomenon mimics the findings of [15, Thm. 2.1] for the Schrödinger case. For $m=0$, rather than a clear-cut split, the spectrum smears throughout the full band that forms the numerical range. In Lemma 3.4 we show that, at any $z$ in the point spectrum, $\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)$ is Fredholm with index zero. Moreover, the geometric multiplicity of $z$ is one while its algebraic multiplicity is infinite. This is neither obvious, nor a consequence of general principles.

Let us now describe the pseudospectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. We adopt the following terminology, which is convenient in order to articulate our findings. We say that a closed operator $\mathscr{L}$ has a trivial pseudospectrum, if there exists a constant $C \geq 1$ such that

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\varepsilon}(\mathscr{L}) \subseteq\{z \in \mathbb{C}: \operatorname{dist}(z, \operatorname{Spec} \mathscr{L}) \leq C \varepsilon\}
$$

for all $\varepsilon>0$. Any normal operator has a trivial pseudospectrum with $C=1$, since in this case the $\varepsilon$ pseudospectrum coincides with the $\varepsilon$-neighbourhood of the spectrum. Any closed operator which is similar to a normal operator, via a bounded invertible similarity transformation $S$, has also trivial pseudospectrum with $C=\|S\|\left\|S^{-1}\right\|$, the condition number of $S$.

According to the well-known inequalities

$$
\frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}\left(z, \operatorname{Spec} \mathscr{L}_{m}\right)} \leq\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}\left(z, \operatorname{Num} \mathscr{L}_{m}\right)}
$$

for all $z \notin \operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$, it is readily seen that for $|\operatorname{Im} z|>1$,

1) and for $|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m$,

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\|=\frac{1}{|\operatorname{Im} z|-1}
$$

2) while for $|\operatorname{Re} z|<m$,

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(|\operatorname{Re} z|-m\right)^{2}+\left(|\operatorname{Im} z|-1\right)^{2}}} \leq\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{1}{|\operatorname{Im} z|-1}
$$

In the next theorem we see that, in stark contrast, the resolvent norm increases at a quadratic rate as $z \rightarrow \infty$ inside the numerical range. This statement is our first main contribution.
Theorem 2.1. Let $m>0$ and let $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ be the operator given by (2.3). Assume that $z \in \mathbb{C}$ is such that $|\operatorname{Im} z|<1$. Then,

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\|=\frac{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}{m\left(1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}\right)}\left(1+\mathcal{O}\left(|\operatorname{Re} z|^{-2}\right)\right)
$$

as $|\operatorname{Re} z| \rightarrow \infty$. The $\mathcal{O}$ term is uniform in $|\operatorname{Im} z|$ and locally uniform in $m$ (i.e., the constants involved can be chosen independent of $z \in \mathbb{C}$ for all $|\operatorname{Im} z|<1$ and $m$ on any fixed compact subset of $(0, \infty)$ ).

According to this theorem, when we consider the level set

$$
\left\{z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right):\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\|=\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right\}
$$

for some $\varepsilon>0$, we obtain curves whose points $z \in \mathbb{C}$ satisfy

$$
|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}=1-\frac{\varepsilon|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}{m}\left(1+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}\right)\right)
$$

in the asymptotic regime $|\operatorname{Re} z| \rightarrow+\infty$. Motivated by this, for $\alpha \in(0,1)$ and $\varepsilon>0$, we set regions

$$
\Lambda_{+}^{\alpha}(\varepsilon)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1+\varepsilon \text { and }|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2} \geq \frac{m\left(1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}\right)}{(1 \pm \alpha) \varepsilon}\right\}
$$

These are illustrated in Figure 4 for two different values of $\varepsilon$.
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 4. Regions $\Lambda_{+}^{0.1}(\varepsilon)$ and $\Lambda_{-}^{0.1}(\varepsilon)$ in the box as shown, for $m=1, \varepsilon=0.02$ (left) and $\varepsilon=0.01$ (right). The part in blue corresponds to $\Lambda_{+}^{0.1}(\varepsilon) \backslash \Lambda_{-}^{0.1}(\varepsilon)$ and $\Lambda_{-}^{0.1}(\varepsilon)$ is shows in brick.

In the next corollary we establish sharp inclusions and exclusion zones for the pseudospectra of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ in terms of these regions. Note that $\mathscr{L}_{0}$ has trivial pseudospectra although it is a non-normal operator.

Corollary 2.2. Let $m \geq 0$ and let $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ be the operator given by (2.3).

1) If $m=0$, then the pseudospectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{0}$ is trivial and for all $\varepsilon>0$,

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\varepsilon}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1+\varepsilon\}
$$

2) If $m>0$, then the pseudospectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is non-trivial. Namely, for every fixed $\alpha \in(0,1)$, there exists $M>0$ such that,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Lambda_{+}^{\alpha}(\varepsilon) \cap\{|\operatorname{Re} z|>M\} & \subset\left(\operatorname{Spec}_{\varepsilon} \mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \cap\{|\operatorname{Re} z|>M\} \\
\left(\operatorname{Spec}_{\varepsilon} \mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \cap\{|\operatorname{Re} z|>M\} & \subset \Lambda_{+}^{\alpha}(\varepsilon) \cap\{|\operatorname{Re} z|>M\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\varepsilon>0$.
Proof. For $m=0$, the statement follows directly from the spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{0}$ and (2.5). Here is the proof for $m>0$. According to Theorem 2.1, there exists a constant $C>0$ such that

$$
\left(1-\frac{C}{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}\right) \frac{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}{m\left(1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}\right)}<\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\|<\left(1+\frac{C}{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}\right) \frac{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}{m\left(1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}\right)}
$$

for large $|\operatorname{Re}(z)|$ and $|\operatorname{Im} z|<1$. Thus, for fixed $\alpha \in(0,1)$ and $|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq \sqrt{\frac{C}{\alpha}}$ we have the following. For $\varepsilon>0,(2.7)$ is ensured whenever $|\operatorname{Re} z|$ is such that

$$
(1-\alpha) \frac{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}{m\left(1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}\right)} \geq \frac{1}{\varepsilon}
$$

Similarly, if

$$
\frac{1}{\varepsilon} \leq\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\|
$$

then

$$
\frac{1}{\varepsilon}<(1+\alpha) \frac{|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}}{m\left(1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}\right)}
$$

Therefore (2.8) is valid. For $|\operatorname{Im} z|>1$, we recall (2.5).
2.2. Long-range potential perturbations. In Section 5 we examine perturbations of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ by an integrable matrix-valued function $V$. We establish results about the localisation of eigenvalues and pseudospectrum, under general assumptions on the decay of $V$ at infinity.

Our starting point is the construction of a specific closed densely defined extension of the differential operator

$$
\mathscr{L}_{m}+V: H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \cap \operatorname{Dom}(V) \longrightarrow L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)
$$

via a version of the classical selfadjoint framework of Kato [17], obtained in [13]. Concretely, for almost ${ }^{1}$ all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, let

$$
V(x)=B(x) A(x) \quad \text { where } \quad B(x)=U(x)|V(x)|^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad A(x)=|V(x)|^{1 / 2}
$$

in the polar decomposition $V(x)=U(x)|V(x)|$, for $U(x)$ partial isometries and $|V|(x)=\left(V^{*}(x) V(x)\right)^{1 / 2}$. Consider the family of closed operators

$$
Q(z)=\overline{A R_{0}(z) B}, \quad \text { where } \quad R_{0}(z)=\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}
$$

for $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. According to Theorem A. 1 quoted in Appendix A, if
H1: there exists $z_{0} \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$ such that $-1 \in \rho\left(Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)$,
then there exists a closed extension $\mathscr{L}_{m, V} \supseteq \mathscr{L}_{m}+V$, whose resolvent coincides with the family of bounded operators

$$
R_{0}(z)-\overline{R_{0}(z) B}\left(I+Q(z)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}(z)
$$

Our analysis below refers to the closed operator $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$.
We begin Section 5 by showing that the abstract condition H1 holds, for a measurable function $V$ satisfying either of the following hypotheses;

H2: $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<1$,
H3: $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right) \cap L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ for some $p \in(1, \infty]$.
Once we settle that, we formulate the next spectral stability result.
Proposition 2.3. Let $m \geq 0$ and let $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ be as in (2.3). Let $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ and assume that either H2 or H3 holds true. Then, there exists a closed densely defined extension $\mathscr{L}_{m, V} \supseteq \mathscr{L}_{m}+V$ with a non-empty resolvent set and its spectrum is as follows.
If $m>0$,

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Here and elsewhere below we assume without further mentioning that all the identities involving point-wise evaluation are valid almost everywhere with respect to the Borel $\sigma$-algebra on $\mathbb{R}$.

1) all the essential spectra of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ are stable and coincide, namely

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=S_{m}, \quad \forall \mathrm{j} \in[[1,5]]
$$

If $m=0$,
2) all the first four notions of essential spectra are stable and coincide, namely

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0, V}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\}, \quad \forall \mathrm{j} \in[[1,4]]
$$

Moreover,
3) If $V$ satisfies the assumption $\mathbf{H} 2$, we have

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0, V}\right) \subset S_{0}
$$

4) If $V$ satisfies the assumption $\mathbf{H} 3$ for $p<\infty$, we have

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0, V}\right) \subset\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1+\frac{2(p-1)}{p}\|V\| \frac{\varepsilon}{L^{p}}\right\}
$$

If $V$ satisfies the assumption $\mathbf{H} 3$ for $p=\infty$, then

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0, V}\right) \subset\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1+\|V\|_{L^{\infty}}\right\}
$$

In Remark 5.1, we expand further on the justification for the condition $\mathbf{H} 2$ and compare with the case of the dislocated Schrödinger operator. This assumption has already been documented in [8] for $\mathcal{D}_{m}$ in place of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. Noticeably, it gives regions of inclusion for the perturbed eigenvalues. Our next result shows that a control on $\|V\|_{L^{1}}$ also gives inclusions for the spectrum and pseudospectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$.

Theorem 2.4. For $m \geq 0$, let

$$
D=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<\frac{3}{2},|\operatorname{Re} z|<\frac{5}{2} m\right\}
$$

There exists a constant $0<C(m) \leq 1$ such that, if $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<C(m)$, then

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\varepsilon}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}\right) \subseteq \bar{D} \cup\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1+\varepsilon\left(1+\frac{\|V\|_{L^{1}}}{4 C(m)\left(C(m)-\|V\|_{L^{1}}\right)}\right)\right\}
$$

for all $\varepsilon \geq 0$. Moreover, for $C(0)=1$ this statement is valid.
According to [8, Cor. 4.6], $\mathcal{D}_{m}+V$ has point spectrum lying on a strip covering the real axis for $m=0$. According to [8, Thm. 2.1], for $m>0$, it lies inside two disks centered near the endpoints of the essential spectrum. The radius of these disks decreases as $\|V\|_{L^{1}} \rightarrow 0$. Our next result shows that, rather unexpectedly, the point spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ behaves differently from that of $\mathcal{D}_{m}+V$, under fast rates of decay of the perturbation at infinity. Namely, it escapes to infinity through the channel created by the numerical range, rather than concentrating at the end-points of the essential spectrum, as $\|V\|_{L^{1}} \rightarrow 0$. The condition we impose is analogous to the one considered in [15, Thm. 2.3] and in turn allows refined versions of the conclusions 3) - 4) of Proposition 2.3 for $m>0$.

Here and everywhere below we write

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\nu_{1}^{\prime}(x)=\sqrt{1+x^{2}}, & \mathrm{~d} \nu_{1}(x)=\nu_{1}^{\prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x \\
\nu_{2}^{\prime}(x)=\nu_{1}^{\prime}(x)^{2}=1+x^{2}, & \mathrm{~d} \nu_{2}(x)=\nu_{2}^{\prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x
\end{array}
$$

Theorem 2.5. Let $m>0$ be fixed. Then, there exists a constant $C(m)>0$, ensuring the following. For all $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} ; \mathrm{d} \nu_{1}\right)$ such that

$$
\|V\|_{L^{1}\left(\mathrm{~d} \nu_{1}\right)}<C(m)
$$

we have

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}\right) \subseteq\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1,|\operatorname{Re}(z)|>\frac{C(m)}{\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right\}
$$

Succinctly, this theorem says that for potentials $V$ decaying sufficiently rapidly at $\infty$, the discrete spectrum escapes to $\infty$ inside the instability band, $\{|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\}$, at a rate proportional to $\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}$ in the regime $\|V\|_{L^{1}} \rightarrow 0$. In the conclusion, the norm is taken with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

For Schrödinger operators, a similar result was established in [15, Thm. 2.3]. In the latter, the density considered was $\nu_{2}^{\prime}$ instead of $\nu_{1}^{\prime}$, and upper bounds for the norm of $Q(z)$ were obtained via the HilbertSchmidt norm. Here we employ the Schur Test instead, which allows a better control of the upper bounds for the norm of the integral operator $Q(z)$. Therefore, we manage to weaken the condition on the decay of $V$.

Theorem 2.5 opens the question of whether there exist $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ with non-empty discrete spectrum for $m>0$. We give an answer to this question in Subsection 5.3. Our concrete finding in this respect is the following. Consider the step potential

$$
V(x)=V_{a, b}(x)=(-i \operatorname{sgn}(x)-b) \chi_{]-a, a]}(x) I
$$

where $a>0$ and $b \in \mathbb{R}$. Set $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V_{a, b}}\right)=H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. According to Proposition 2.3, the essential spectra of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V_{a, b}}$ are

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V_{a, b}}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1,|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m\}
$$

for all $\mathrm{j} \in[[1,4]]$, including $\mathrm{j}=5$ if $m>0$.
Proposition 2.6. For $m \geq 0$, let $\mathscr{L}_{m, V_{a, b}}$ be as in the previous paragraph.

1) If $m=0$, then the point spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{0, V_{a, b}}$ is the band

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0, V_{a, b}}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\}
$$

2) If $m>0$, then the operator $\mathscr{L}_{m, V_{a, b}}$ has infinitely many isolated real eigenvalues accumulating at $\pm \infty$.

In the context of Theorem 2.5, it is also natural to examine the behaviour of the family of operators $\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}$ for fixed $m>0$, fixed potential $V$ and a small moving complex parameter $\epsilon \in \mathbb{C}$, in the regime $|\epsilon| \rightarrow 0$. This is the so-called weakly coupled model. For this model we establish the following in Subsection 5.4.

Let $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} ; \mathrm{d} \nu_{1}\right)$. From Proposition 2.3 and Theorem 2.5, it follows that

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{ej}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1,|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m\}, \quad \forall j \in[[1,5]]
$$

and, for a suitable constant $C(m)>0$,

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{dis}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right) \subseteq\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1,|\operatorname{Re} z|>\frac{C(m)}{|\epsilon|^{\frac{1}{2}}\|V\|_{L}^{1}}\right\}
$$

for all $|\epsilon|$ small enough. If $V$ satisfies additional conditions of regularity and decay at infinity, then Theorem 2.5 refines as follows.

Theorem 2.7. Let $m>0$. For any $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} ; \mathrm{d} \nu_{2}\right) \cap W^{2,1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$, there exists a constant $C(m)>0$ independent of $\epsilon$, such that

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{dis}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right) \subset\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1,|\operatorname{Re} z|>\frac{C(m)}{|\epsilon|}\right\}
$$

for all $|\epsilon|$ small enough.

# 3. RESOLYENT AND SPECTRUM OF $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ 

In this section we settle the framework of the differential expression (2.3) and the associated linear operator. We begin by determining $\operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. We then compute the Green matrix associated with the resolvent $\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}$ and find $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$.

Since $\mathcal{D}_{m}^{*}=\mathcal{D}_{m}$ and multiplication by $i \operatorname{sgn}(x) I$ is bounded, it follows that the domain of $\mathscr{L}_{m}^{*}$ is also $H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. Let $\mathcal{T}$ be the antilinear operator of complex conjugation, $\mathcal{T} g=\bar{g}$ and $\mathcal{P}$ be the parity operator, $(\mathcal{P} g)(x)=g(-x)$. For $f \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, direct substitution of the operators involved, gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathcal{T} \mathscr{L}_{m} \mathcal{T} f\right)(x) & =\overline{\left(-i \partial_{x}\right) \sigma_{2} \overline{f(x)}+m \sigma_{3} \overline{f(x)}+i \operatorname{sgn}(x) \overline{f(x)}} \\
& =\left(-i \partial_{x}\right) \sigma_{2} f(x)+m \sigma_{3} f(x)-i \operatorname{sgn}(x) f(x)=\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}^{*} f\right)(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

however,

$$
\mathcal{P} \mathcal{T} \mathscr{L}_{m} f \neq \mathscr{L}_{m} \mathcal{P} \mathcal{T} f
$$

Therefore, $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is $\mathcal{T}$-selfadjoint but it is not $\mathcal{P} \mathcal{T}$-symmetric.
Now we show that

$$
\operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1\}
$$

Indeed, let $f=\binom{f_{1}}{f_{2}} \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$ be such that $\|f\|=1$. Integration by parts gives

$$
\left\langle\mathscr{L}_{m} f, f\right\rangle=m\left(\left\|f_{1}\right\|^{2}-\left\|f_{2}\right\|^{2}\right)+2 \operatorname{Re}\left\langle f_{1}^{\prime}, f_{2}\right\rangle+i\left(\|f\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}^{2}-\|f\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}\right)}^{2}\right)
$$

Since $\|f\|=1$, it follows immediately that $\left|\operatorname{Im}\left\langle\mathscr{L}_{m} f, f\right\rangle\right| \leq 1$, which implies that

$$
\operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \subseteq\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1\}
$$

Conversely, for the reverse inclusion, we construct appropriate test functions as follows. Choose smooth $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ with supports in $\mathbb{R}_{+}$such that $\left\|g_{1}\right\|^{2}+\left\|g_{2}\right\|^{2}=1$ and $\operatorname{Re}\left\langle g_{1}^{\prime}, g_{2}\right\rangle>0$. For $\lambda>0$, let

$$
f_{j}(x)=\lambda^{1 / 2} g_{j}(\lambda x)
$$

Then, $\|f\|=1$ and

$$
\left\langle\mathscr{L}_{m} f, f\right\rangle=m\left(\left\|g_{1}\right\|^{2}-\left\|g_{2}\right\|^{2}\right)+2 \operatorname{ARe}\left\langle g_{1}^{\prime}, g_{2}\right\rangle+i
$$

Hence, by increasing $\lambda$, it follows that $\mathbb{R}_{+}+i \subseteq \operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. Similar arguments, choosing $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ with support in $\mathbb{R}_{-}$or changing the sign of $\operatorname{Re}\left\langle g_{1}^{\prime}, g_{2}\right\rangle$, give $\mathbb{R} \pm i \subseteq \operatorname{Num}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. The convexity of the numerical range completes the proof of (3.2).

Below, we often write $\Sigma=\operatorname{Int}\left(\operatorname{Num} \mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$ and call this set the instability band.
3.1. Integral form of the resolvent. In this subsection we compute explicitly the integral kernel associated to the resolvent of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. We also establish preliminary estimates on its norm. We begin by fixing a notation that will prove crucial for simplifying our expressions and subsequent analysis.

For $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash\{ \pm m \pm i\}$, we write

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mu_{z}^{-}=\sqrt{(m+i+z)(m-i-z)}, & \mu_{z}^{+}=\sqrt{(m-i+z)(m+i-z)} \\
w_{z}^{-}=\frac{m-i-z}{\mu_{z}^{-}}=\frac{\sqrt{m-i-z}}{\sqrt{m+i+z}}, & w_{z}^{+}=\frac{m+i-z}{\mu_{z}^{+}}=\frac{\sqrt{m+i-z}}{\sqrt{m-i+z}}
\end{array}
$$

Here and throughout the paper, we pick the principal branch $z \mapsto \sqrt{z}=z^{\frac{1}{2}}$ defined on $\mathbb{C}$, holomorphic on $\mathbb{C} \backslash(-\infty, 0]$ and having a positive imaginary part on $(-\infty, 0)$. This choice ensures that $w_{z}^{ \pm}$have the stated expressions in (3.3).

Since

$$
(m \pm i+z)(m \mp i-z) \in(-\infty, 0] \quad \Longleftrightarrow \quad|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m \text { and } \operatorname{Im} z=\mp 1
$$

then

$$
\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}>0 \quad \Longleftrightarrow \quad z \notin\{\tau \pm i: \tau \in \mathbb{R},|\tau| \geq m\}
$$

Moreover, $\overline{\mu_{z}^{ \pm}}=\mu_{y}^{ \mp}$and $\overline{w_{z}^{ \pm}}=w_{z}^{ \mp}$ for all $z$ satisfying (3.4). Below we will use these facts repeatedly, often without further explicit mention.

Recall $S_{m}$ given by (2.1). In the next subsection, we will establish that $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=S_{m}$. For $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m}$, define the matrices

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
N_{1, z}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 / w_{z}^{-} & 1 \\
1 & w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right), & N_{0, z}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 / w_{z}^{+} & 1 \\
-1 & w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right) \\
N_{2, z}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 / w_{z}^{-} & -1 \\
1 & w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right), & N_{7, z}=N_{4, z} \\
N_{3, z}=\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & -w_{z}^{-} \\
w_{z}^{+} & w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right), & N_{8, z}=\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & w_{z}^{+} \\
-w_{z}^{-} & w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right) \\
N_{4, z}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 / w_{z}^{+} & 1 \\
1 & -w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right), & N_{9, z}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 / w_{z}^{-} & 1 \\
-1 & w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right) \\
N_{5, z}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 / w_{z}^{+} & -1 \\
1 & w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right), & N_{10, z}=N_{1, z}
\end{array}
$$

For $x, y \in \mathbb{R}, x \neq y$, let the matrix kernel $\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)$ be given in regions of the plane $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ by

$$
\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)= \begin{cases}N_{1, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x+y)}+N_{2, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)}, & \text { for } y<x<0 \\ N_{3, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} x+\mu_{z}^{-}y}, & \text { for } y<0<x \\ N_{4, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x+y)}+N_{5, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}, & \text { for } 0<y<x \\ N_{6, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}+N_{7, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x+y)}, & \text { for } 0<x<y \\ N_{8, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-} x-\mu_{z}^{+} y}, & \text { for } x<0<y \\ N_{9, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)}+N_{10, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x+y)}, & \text { for } x<y<0\end{cases}
$$

Note that $\mathcal{R}_{z}$ is continuous across the lines $x=0$ and $y=0$, but discontinuous across the line $x=y$. Here it is not important what values we give to this matrix function on these lines, so we leave them unassigned.

We also mention that, in contrast to the case of the resolvent kernel of the Schrödinger operator $-\frac{d^{2}}{d z^{2}}+$ $i \operatorname{sgn}(x)$, considered in [15, Prop. 3.1], $\mathcal{R}_{z}$ is not symmetric with respect to the line $x=y$. We will see in Lemma 3.2 that the induced operator norm of $\mathcal{R}_{z}$ is nonetheless symmetric. That is, $\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}=$ $\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(y, x)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}$ for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$.

As we shall see from the next statements, $\mathcal{R}_{z}$ is the (matrix) Green function associated to the operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}-z$. This explicit formula has a far reaching role in the analysis that we conduct below. Remarkably, we will see that it enables the systematic study of perturbation of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ via a Birman-Schwinger principle, as described in Section 5.
Proposition 3.1. For $m \geq 0$, let $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ be the operator given by (2.3). Then, $\mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m} \subset \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. Moreover,

$$
\left[\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1} f\right](x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} \mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

for all $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m}$ and $f \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$,
Before proceeding to the proof, we highlight that the resolvent kernel of the free Dirac operator [8, Proof of Thm. 2.1], is a convolution kernel and it contains only exponential terms involving the difference $x-y$. By contrast, for $m>0, \mathcal{R}_{z}$ also includes mixed exponential terms and it cannot be expressed as a pure tensor product of two matrix functions. We will see below that this more complex structure of the Green function is responsible for the asymptotic growth of the resolvent norm inside the numerical range.

The remainder of this section is devoted to the proof of Proposition 3.1. Although this proof follows a routine argumentation, we include crucial details that will aid in the computation of sharp estimates for the resolvent norm. We split it into 4 steps.
Step 1. Fix $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m}$ and $f \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. Consider the eigenvalue equation

$$
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right) u=f
$$

which in matrix form reads

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
m+i \operatorname{sgn}(x)-z & -\partial_{x} \\
\partial_{x} & -m+i \operatorname{sgn}(x)-z
\end{array}\right)\binom{u_{1}(x)}{u_{2}(x)}=\binom{f_{1}(x)}{f_{2}(x)}
$$

Our final goal in the proof is to determine the explicit integral expression for the solution. Multiplying by the matrix $J=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array}\right)$ on the left of the two sides of (3.7), gives the equivalent non-homogeneous linear system of first order,

$$
\partial_{x} u(x)=A_{z}(x) u(x)+g(x)
$$

where

$$
A_{z}(x)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & m-i \operatorname{sgn}(x)+z \\
m+i \operatorname{sgn}(x)-z & 0
\end{array}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad g(x)=-J f(x)
$$

We now seek for the solution of this system.
Consider the equation (3.8) for $x>0$ and $x<0$, where the corresponding solutions are indicated as $u_{-}$ and $u_{+}$. Let

$$
A_{z}^{-}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & m+i+z \\
m-i-z & 0
\end{array}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad A_{z}^{+}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & m-i+z \\
m+i-z & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

be the expressions for $A_{z}(x)$ for $x>0$ and $x<0$, respectively. Let $\Phi_{z}^{\pm}(x)$ be fundamental matrices for $\partial_{x} u_{ \pm}=A_{z}^{ \pm} u^{ \pm}$. The columns of $\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x)$ ought to be linear independent for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, thus, we can pick the choice

$$
\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x)=\exp \left(A_{z}^{ \pm} x\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\cosh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right) & \frac{\sinh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right)}{w_{z}^{ \pm}} \\
w_{z}^{ \pm} \sinh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right) & \cosh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right)
\end{array}\right)
$$

Note that

$$
\left(\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x)\right)^{-1}=\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(-x) \quad \text { and } \quad \Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) \Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(y)=\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x+y)
$$

We now determine the solutions $u_{ \pm}$of the inhomogeneous system

$$
\partial_{x} u_{ \pm}(x)=A_{z}^{ \pm} u_{ \pm}(x)+g(x) \quad \text { on } \quad \mathbb{R}_{ \pm}
$$

in the form $u_{ \pm}(x)=\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) v_{ \pm}(x)$, where $v_{ \pm}: \mathbb{R}_{ \pm} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}^{2}$ are to be determined. Taking the derivative of $u_{ \pm}$ and using (3.9), we obtain

$$
\partial_{x} u_{ \pm}(x)=A_{z}^{ \pm} \Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) v_{ \pm}(x)+\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) \partial_{x} v_{ \pm}(x)=A_{z}^{ \pm} u_{ \pm}(x)+\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) \partial_{x} v_{ \pm}(x) \quad \text { on } \quad \mathbb{R}_{ \pm}
$$

Therefore, $u_{ \pm}$are solutions of (3.11) if and only if $\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) \partial_{x} v_{ \pm}(x)=g(x)$ on $\mathbb{R}_{ \pm}$. Hence, we choose

$$
v_{ \pm}(x)=\int_{0}^{x}\left(\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(y)\right)^{-1} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\binom{\alpha_{ \pm}}{\beta_{ \pm}}
$$

where $\alpha_{ \pm}, \beta_{ \pm} \in \mathbb{C}$ are constants to be determined. Then, the general solutions of (3.11) are given by

$$
u_{ \pm}(x)=\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x) \int_{0}^{x}\left(\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(y)\right)^{-1} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x)\binom{\alpha_{ \pm}}{\beta_{ \pm}}
$$

As the condition

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} u_{-}(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} u_{+}(x)
$$

is needed for a solution to be in the domain of the operator, then necessarily

$$
\binom{\alpha_{-}}{\beta_{-}}=\binom{\alpha_{+}}{\beta_{+}}=\vdots\binom{\alpha}{\beta}
$$

This gives the appropriate regularity to the solution for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
Step 2. Our next objective is to determine $\alpha$ and $\beta$ such that $u_{ \pm}$decay to zero at infinity. According to (3.10), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{ \pm}(x) & =\int_{0}^{x} \Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x-y) g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\Phi_{z}^{ \pm}(x)\binom{\alpha}{\beta} \\
& =\int_{0}^{x}\binom{\cosh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm}(x-y)\right)}{w_{z}^{ \pm} \sinh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm}(x-y)\right)} \frac{\sinh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm}(x-y)\right)}{\frac{w_{z}^{ \pm}}{w_{z}^{ \pm}} \frac{\sinh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right)}{w_{z}^{ \pm}} \frac{\sinh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right)}{w_{z}^{ \pm}} \cosh \left(\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x\right)}\left(\frac{\alpha}{\beta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Writing the right-hand side in exponential form, reduces to

$$
u_{ \pm}(x)=\int_{0}^{x} e^{\mu_{z}^{ \pm}(x-y)} S_{z}^{ \pm} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+e^{\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x} S_{z}^{ \pm}\binom{\alpha}{\beta}+\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm}(x-y)} T_{z}^{ \pm} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x} T_{z}^{ \pm}\binom{\alpha}{\beta}
$$

where

$$
S_{z}^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 1 / w_{z}^{ \pm} \\
w_{z}^{ \pm} & 1
\end{array}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad T_{z}^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -1 / w_{z}^{ \pm} \\
-w_{z}^{ \pm} & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

We seek for conditions ensuring $\lim _{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} u_{ \pm}(x)=0$. Since the function $g$ belongs to $L^{2}$ but not necessarily to $L^{1}$, we cannot use directly the Dominated Convergence Theorem. Instead, we appeal to the density of $C_{\epsilon}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ in $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ as follows. For $\epsilon>0$ small, let $g_{\epsilon} \in C_{\epsilon}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ be such that $\left\|g-g_{\epsilon}\right\|<\epsilon$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)} T_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \leq & \int_{0}^{x} e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}\left|T_{z}^{+}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\left|g(y)-g_{\epsilon}(y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y \\
& +\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}\left|T_{z}^{+}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\left|g_{\epsilon}(y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y \\
\leq & \left|T_{z}^{+}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \sqrt{\frac{1-e^{-2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+} x}}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}}\left\|g-g_{\epsilon}\right\| \\
& +\left|T_{z}^{+}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \int_{0}^{x} e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}\left|g_{\epsilon}(y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall (3.4). Since $\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}>0$, the integrand $e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}\left|g_{\epsilon}(y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}$ is bounded by the $L^{1}$ function $\left|g_{\epsilon}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}$, then, according to the Dominated Convergence Theorem, we have

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty}\left|\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)} T_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \leq\left|T_{z}^{+}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}}
$$

Because $\epsilon$ is arbitrary, the limit on the left-hand side is zero. In turn, we gather that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} u_{+}(x)=0 & \Longleftrightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} e^{\mu_{z}^{+} x}\left(\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} y} S_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+S_{z}^{+}\binom{\alpha}{\beta}\right)=0 \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \quad S_{z}^{+}\binom{\alpha}{\beta}=-\int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} y} S_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \quad \alpha+\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}} \beta=-\int_{0}^{+\infty}\left(g_{1}(y)+\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}} g_{2}(y)\right) e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

For the latter note that $\operatorname{det} S_{z}^{+}=0$.
Similarly, by considering the limit to $-\infty$, we conclude that

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow-\infty} u_{-}(x)=0 \Longleftrightarrow \alpha-\frac{1}{w_{z}^{-}} \beta=\int_{-\infty}^{0}\left(g_{1}(y)-\frac{1}{w_{z}^{-}} g_{2}(y)\right) e^{\mu_{z}^{-} y} \mathrm{~d} y
$$

Now, (3.14)-(3.15) can be re-written as a single linear system of equations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 1 / w_{z}^{+} \\
1 & -1 / w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right)\binom{\alpha}{\beta}= & \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} y}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & -1 / w_{z}^{+} \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right) g(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{\mu_{z}^{-} y}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 0 \\
1 & -1 / w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right) g(y) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Since

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 1 / w_{z}^{+} \\
1 & -1 / w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right) \neq 0
$$

for all $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m}$, then

$$
\binom{\alpha}{\beta}=\int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} y} M_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{\mu_{z}^{-} y} M_{z}^{-} g(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

where

$$
M_{z}^{+}=\frac{-1}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
w_{z}^{+} & 1 \\
w_{z}^{+} w_{z}^{-} & w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right), \quad M_{z}^{-}=\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
w_{z}^{-} & -1 \\
-w_{z}^{+} w_{z}^{-} & w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Step 3. We now verify the expression for the matrix integral kernel $\mathcal{R}_{z}$. Replacing the constant vector $\binom{\alpha}{\beta}$ into the formula for $u_{ \pm}$, gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{ \pm}(x)= & \int_{0}^{x} e^{\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)} S_{z}^{ \pm} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x-\mu_{z}^{+} y} S_{z}^{ \pm} M_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x+\mu_{z}^{-} y} S_{z}^{ \pm} M_{z}^{-} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)} T_{z}^{ \pm} g(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x-\mu_{z}^{+} y} T_{z}^{ \pm} M_{z}^{+} g(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x+\mu_{z}^{-} y} T_{z}^{ \pm} M_{z}^{-} g(y) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $S_{z}^{+} M_{z}^{+}=-S_{z}^{+}, S_{z}^{+} M_{z}^{-}=0$ and $g=-J f$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{+}(x)= & \int_{x}^{+\infty} N_{9, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{0}^{x} N_{5, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\int_{0}^{+\infty} N_{4, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x+y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{-\infty}^{0} N_{3, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} x+\mu_{z}^{-} y} f(y) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, since $T_{z}^{-} M_{z}^{-}=T_{z}^{-}$and $T_{z}^{-} M_{z}^{+}=0$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{-}(x)= & \int_{-\infty}^{x} N_{2, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{x}^{0} N_{9, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\int_{-\infty}^{0} N_{1, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x+y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{0}^{+\infty} N_{8, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-} x-\mu_{z}^{+} y} f(y) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Step 4. So far, we have obtained a solution to (3.7) on $\mathbb{R}$, which is continuous and decaying at infinity. This solution has the form

$$
u(x)= \begin{cases}u_{+}(x) & \text { if } x \geq 0 \\ u_{-}(x) & \text { if } x \leq 0\end{cases}
$$

and has the integral representation

$$
u(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} \mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

as in the statement of Proposition 3.1. To complete the proof, it remains to check that $u \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ and thus $\mathscr{L}_{m} u=z u+f \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, so that $u \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. This will be the consequence of the next two lemmas, which will be useful in their own right later on.

Firstly, we explicitly compute the matrix norm of the kernel.
Lemma 3.2. Let $\mathcal{R}_{z}$ be as defined in (3.5). Assume that $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m}$ is fixed. Let

$$
\varphi_{z}(t)= \begin{cases}\frac{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}}}{2}\left(\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}}\left|k_{z} e^{2 \mu_{z}^{-} t}-1\right|^{2}+\left|k_{z} e^{2 \mu_{z}^{-} t}+1\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}, & \text { for } t \leq 0 \\ \frac{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}}}{2}\left(\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+} t}+1\right|^{2}+\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+} t}-1\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}, & \text { for } t \geq 0\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
k_{z}=\frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}
$$

Then, $\varphi_{z}: \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$is bounded and continuous, and

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}= \begin{cases}\varphi_{z}(\max \{x, y\}) e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{-}|x-y|}, & \text { for } x<0, y<0 \\ \varphi_{z}(\min \{x, y\}) e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{+}|x-y|}, & \text { for } x>0, y>0 \\ \varphi_{z}(0) e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{+}|x|-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{-}|y|}, & \text { for } x>0, y<0 \\ \varphi_{z}(0) e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{-}|x|-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{+}|y|}, & \text { for } x<0, y>0\end{cases}
$$

Proof. The function $\varphi_{z}$ is continuous, since

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0_{-}} \varphi_{z}(t)=\frac{\sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{ \pm}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|w_{x}^{ \pm}+w_{x}^{-}\right|}=\lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} \varphi_{z}(t)
$$

It is bounded, since

$$
\sup _{t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}} \varphi_{z}(t) \leq\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right) \frac{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{x}^{ \pm}\right|^{2}}}{2} \sqrt{1+\frac{1}{\left|w_{x}^{ \pm}\right|^{2}}}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right)\left(\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|}\right)
$$

Now, recall that, for a singular matrix $A \in \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}$, the operator norm and the Frobenius norm coincide

$$
|A|_{L^{2 \times 2}}=\sqrt{\sum_{1 \leq i, j \leq 2}\left|A_{i j}\right|^{2}}
$$

Indeed, $\operatorname{det}\left(A^{*} A\right)=0$, therefore the two non-negative eigenvalues of $A^{*} A$ are 0 and $\operatorname{Tr}\left(A^{*} A\right)$. Applying this, alongside a straightforward computation, gives

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|^{2}}}{2}\left(\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|^{2}}\left|k_{z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm}|x+y|} \pm e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm}|x-y|}\right|^{2}\right. \\
\left.+\left|k_{z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm}|x+y|} \mp e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm}|x-y|}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}, \quad \text { for } \pm x>0 \text { and } \pm y>0 \\
\frac{\sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right|} e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}|x|-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}|y|}, \quad \text { for } \pm x>0 \text { and } \pm y<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

Factoring out suitable exponential terms and substitution of the expression (3.18) yields (3.20).

The next lemma directly implies that the function $u$ given by (3.17) belongs to $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, and hence $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. This conclusion completes the proof of Proposition 3.1. Additionally, the lemma provides an initial estimate for the upper bound of the resolvent norm of the operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. This estimate is derived directly from the explicit expression of $\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}$ in terms of the supremum of $\varphi_{z}(t)$, using the Schur Test. We will refine this upper bound in the next section.

Lemma 3.3. Let $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash S_{m}$. Then, the integral operator on the right-hand side of (3.17) is bounded on $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, and

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{2}{\min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right\}} \sup _{t \in \mathbb{R}} \varphi_{z}(t)
$$

Proof. We will prove this lemma by the Schur Test. Our goal is to show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} y \leq \frac{2}{\min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right\}} \sup _{t \in \mathbb{R}} \varphi_{z}(t), \quad \text { for a.e. } x \in \mathbb{R}, \\
& \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} x \leq \frac{2}{\min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right\}} \sup _{t \in \mathbb{R}} \varphi_{z}(t), \quad \text { for a.e. } y \in \mathbb{R} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\left.\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\right.$ is symmetric with respect to swapping $x$ and $y$, it suffices to show the first identity in (3.23).

For $x \leq 0$, (3.20) yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} y \\
& =\int_{-\infty}^{x} \varphi_{z}(x) e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}(y-x)} \mathrm{d} y+\int_{x}^{0} \varphi_{z}(y) e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)} \mathrm{d} y+\int_{0}^{+\infty} \varphi_{z}(0) e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}x-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}y} \mathrm{d} y \\
& \leq \varphi_{z}(x) \frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\left(\sup _{t \leq 0} \varphi_{z}(t)\right) \frac{1-e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}x}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\varphi_{z}(0) \frac{e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}x}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}} \\
& \leq\left(\sup _{x \leq 0} \varphi_{z}(x)\right)\left[\frac{2}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\left(\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}\right) e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}x}\right] \\
& \leq\left(\sup _{x \leq 0} \varphi_{z}(x)\right) \frac{2}{\min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right\}}
\end{aligned}
$$

A similar estimate is obtained for $x \geq 0$, where now the supremum is taken for $x \geq 0$. From this, (3.23) follows.
3.2. The spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$. According to Proposition 3.1,

$$
\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \subseteq S_{m}
$$

Since $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is $\mathcal{T}$-selfadjoint, the residual spectrum is empty [20, Sec. 5.2.5.4] and the first four essential spectra coincide [12, Thm. IX.1.6(ii)]. In this subsection we show that the spectrum coincides exactly with $S_{m}$ and find $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 5}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. We treat the case $m=0$ separately.
Case $m>0$. Let $z^{ \pm}=\tau \pm i$ for fixed $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $|\tau| \geq m$, so $z^{ \pm} \in S_{m}$. Our goal is to construct singular Weyl sequences $\left(\Psi_{n}^{ \pm}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ for $z^{ \pm}$, to conclude that they are in the appropriate part of the spectrum. With this purpose in mind, let

$$
u(x)=\binom{\sqrt{|m+\tau|}}{i \operatorname{sgn}(\tau) \sqrt{|m-\tau|}} e^{i \sqrt{\tau^{2}-m^{2}} x}
$$

which is one of the solutions of

$$
\left(\mathcal{D}_{m}-\tau I\right) u=0
$$

for the free Dirac operator (2.2). Let

$$
\Psi_{n}^{ \pm}(x)=c_{n} \varphi_{n}( \pm x) u(x)
$$

where

$$
c_{n}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2|\tau|\left(n+\frac{2}{3}\right)}}
$$

and $\varphi_{n}$ is the continuous compact support cut-off function given by

$$
\varphi_{n}(x)= \begin{cases}x-n & \text { for } x \in[n, n+1] \\ 1 & \text { for } x \in[n+1,2 n+1] \\ 2 n+2-x & \text { for } x \in[2 n+1,2 n+2] \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

Then, $\left\|\Psi_{n}^{ \pm}\right\|=1$.
By considering the location of the supports and from (3.25), it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z^{ \pm} I\right) \Psi_{n}^{ \pm}(x) & =\left(\mathcal{D}_{m}-\tau I\right) \Psi_{n}^{ \pm}(x) \\
& =c_{n} \varphi_{n}( \pm x)\left(\mathcal{D}_{m}-\tau I\right) u(x)+c_{n}\left[\mathcal{D}_{m}-\tau I, \varphi_{n}( \pm x) I\right] u(x) \\
& = \pm c_{n} \varphi_{n}^{\prime}( \pm x) J u(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z^{ \pm} I\right) \Psi_{n}^{ \pm}(x)\right\|=\left\|c_{n} \varphi_{n}^{\prime}( \pm x) J u(x)\right\|=\sqrt{\frac{2}{n+\frac{2}{3}}} \rightarrow 0
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Therefore, indeed, $\left(\Psi_{n}^{ \pm}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is a Weyl sequence for $z^{ \pm}$. Thus, $z^{ \pm} \in \operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. This completes the proof that $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=S_{m}$ for all $m>0$, which we will use without further explicit mention.

Since the support of the Weyl sequence moves to infinity, $S_{m} \subset \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 2}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. Consequently, $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} j}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=$ $S_{m}$ for $\mathrm{j} \in[[1,4]]$. To further deduce that

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 5}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=S_{m}
$$

it suffices to note that $\mathbb{C} \backslash \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 1}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$ is connected [20, Prop. 5.4.4].
Finally, observe that $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mu}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\varnothing$. Indeed, the expression of the fundamental matrices (3.9) is also valid for $z \in S_{m}$. Applying (3.12) with $g=0$ and noting that $\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}=0$ for $z \in\{\tau \pm i:|\tau| \geq m\}$, we conclude that there are no nontrivial solutions to the eigenvalue equation $\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right) u=0$ that belong to $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. Therefore, no point in $S_{m}$ can be an eigenvalue. This completes the description of the spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ for $m>0$.

Case $m=0$. For $\mathscr{L}_{0}$ and $z^{ \pm}=\tau \pm i$ where $\tau \neq 0$, the previous argumentation involving $\left(\Psi_{n}^{ \pm}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is still applicable, so we know that there exist singular Weyl sequences for $z^{ \pm} \neq \pm i$. On the other hand, for $\tau=0$, we can choose constant $u(x)=\binom{1}{0}$ instead of (3.24), which is a solution to the eigenvalue equation (3.25), and run a similar proof as above. Thus, we know up front that

$$
\partial S_{0}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\right\} \subset \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 2}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} j}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)
$$

for $\mathrm{j}=1,3,4$.
Our focus now is to show that all the points $z$ in the interior of the strip $S_{0}$ are eigenvalues with $\mathscr{L}_{0}-z$ being a Fredholm operator of index zero.
Lemma 3.4. For $m=0$, let $\mathscr{L}_{0}$ be defined as in (2.3). Let $z \in \mathbb{C}$ be such that $|\operatorname{Im} z|<1$. Then the following holds true.
a) $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)=\operatorname{span}\left\{v_{z}\right\}$ where

$$
v_{z}(x)= \begin{cases}\binom{1}{-i} e^{(1-i z) x} & \text { for } x \leq 0 \\ \binom{1}{-i} e^{-(1+i z) x} & \text { for } x \geq 0\end{cases}
$$

b) $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}^{*}-z\right)=\operatorname{span}\left\{\widetilde{v}_{z}\right\}$ where

$$
\widetilde{v}_{z}(x)= \begin{cases}\binom{1}{i} e^{(1+i z) x} & \text { for } x \leq 0 \\ \binom{1}{i} e^{-(1-i z) x} & \text { for } x \geq 0\end{cases}
$$

c) $\operatorname{Ran}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)$ is closed.
d) The algebraic multiplicity of $z$ is infinite.

Proof. Consider once again the equation $\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right) u=f$ as in Subsection 3.1. When $m=0$ and $|\operatorname{Im} z|<1$, the quantities $\mu_{z}^{ \pm}, w_{z}^{ \pm}$in (3.3) reduce to

$$
\mu_{z}^{+}=1+i z, \quad \mu_{z}^{-}=1-i z, \quad w_{z}^{+}=i, \quad w_{z}^{-}=-i
$$

We start with the proof of a). Let $u \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ be a solution to this eigenvalue equation. We know that the restrictions of $u$ to $\mathbb{R}_{ \pm}$, match (3.12) with $g=0$, namely

$$
u_{ \pm}(x)=e^{\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x} S_{z}^{ \pm}\binom{\alpha}{\beta}+e^{-\mu_{z}^{ \pm} x} T_{z}^{ \pm}\binom{\alpha}{\beta}
$$

with $(\alpha, \beta) \in \mathbb{C}^{2}$ and

$$
S_{z}^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \mp i \\
\pm i & 1
\end{array}\right), \quad T_{z}^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \pm i \\
\mp i & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

Since $\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}>0$, the decay of $u$ at $\pm \infty$ should match the conditions (3.14) and (3.15) for $\alpha$ and $\beta$. Therefore, $\alpha=i \beta$. Hence

$$
u_{+}(x)=\alpha e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} x}\binom{1}{-i} \quad \text { and } \quad u_{-}(x)=\alpha e^{\mu_{z}^{-} x}\binom{1}{-i}
$$

Thus, indeed a) is valid. The proof of b) is identical, so we omit it.
To confirm c), we will show that $\overline{\operatorname{Ran}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)} \subseteq \operatorname{Ran}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)$. Take $f \in \overline{\operatorname{Ran}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)}$ and seek for $u \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ such that $\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right) u=f$. Now $u_{ \pm}$are given in the form (3.12) with $g=-J f$. Since

$$
\overline{\operatorname{Ran}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}-z\right)}=\left(\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}^{*}-\bar{z}\right)\right)^{\perp}
$$

according to b), it follows that

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{0}\left(f_{1}(y)-i f_{2}(y)\right) e^{(1-i z) y} \mathrm{~d} y+\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(f_{1}(y)-i f_{2}(y)\right) e^{-(1+i z) y} \mathrm{~d} y=0
$$

By proceeding as in the proof of Proposition 3.1, this is equivalent to the fact that both right-hand sides of the decaying conditions (3.14) and (3.15) are equal. That is,

$$
-\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(g_{1}(y)-i g_{2}(y)\right) e^{-\mu_{*}^{+} y} \mathrm{~d} y=\alpha-i \beta=\int_{-\infty}^{0}\left(g_{1}(y)-i g_{2}(y)\right) e^{\mu_{*}^{-} y} \mathrm{~d} y
$$

Set $\beta=0$. Then

$$
\binom{\alpha}{\beta}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & i \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right) \int_{0}^{\infty} g(y) e^{-\mu_{*}^{+} y} \mathrm{~d} y=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -i \\
0 & 0
\end{array}\right) \int_{-\infty}^{0} g(y) e^{\mu_{*}^{-} y} \mathrm{~d} y
$$

Replacing these constants in (3.12) and writing the expression back in terms of $f_{1}$ and $f_{2}$, using $g=-J f$, gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{+}(x)= & C_{1}^{+} \int_{x}^{+\infty} e^{\mu_{*}^{+}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+C_{2}^{+} \int_{0}^{x} e^{-\mu_{*}^{+}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +C_{3}^{+} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\mu_{*}^{+}(x+y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{-}(x)= & C_{1}^{-} \int_{-\infty}^{x} e^{-\mu_{*}^{-}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+C_{2}^{-} \int_{x}^{0} e^{\mu_{*}^{-}(x-y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +C_{3}^{-} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{\mu_{*}^{-}(x+y)} f(y) \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

for suitable constant matrices $C_{j}^{ \pm}$. Now, by invoking the Schur Test in identical manner as in the proof of Proposition 3.1 - we omit the details, we find that $u \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ and thus $u \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. Hence, indeed $f \in \operatorname{Ran}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)$. This completes the proof of $c$ ).

For the final statement, we invoke [23, Thm. 2.16 in Ch. 2], which establishes that only one of the following cases can occur. Either

$$
\Sigma=\{w \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} w|<1 \text { and the algebraic multiplicity of } w \text { is finite }\}
$$

or

$$
\Sigma=\{w \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} w|<1 \text { and the algebraic multiplicity of } w \text { is infinite }\}
$$

From the above, the geometric multiplicity of all $z \in \Sigma$ is one. Therefore no point in $\Sigma$ has algebraic multiplicity zero. Thus, according to [23, Thm. 2.15 in Ch. 2], the set on the right-hand side of the first possibility is countable. But this is not the case for $\Sigma$, hence, the second possibility is the one that holds. This confirms d) and completes the proof of the lemma.

According to Lemma 3.4, we now know that

$$
\operatorname{int} S_{0}=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\} \subseteq \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right) \backslash \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 3}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)
$$

Combining this with (3.27), we conclude that indeed

$$
\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=S_{0} \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} j}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 2}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\right\}
$$

for $\mathrm{j}=1,3,4$. Since no eigenvalue on the left-hand side of (3.31) is isolated, and $S_{0}$ is the closure of its interior, then $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 5}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=S_{0}$. Finally, since no point on the lines $\{\tau \pm i: \tau \in \mathbb{R}\}$ is an eigenvalue, these lines exactly form the continuous spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{0}$. In summary,

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\}
$$

We have therefore completed the analysis of the spectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ for all $m \geq 0$.

# 4. The Resolvent norm of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ inside the numerical range 

Let $m>0$. In the second part of this section we give the proof of the sharp estimate for the resolvent norm of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ claimed in Theorem 2.1. Before that, and in order to visualise the asymptotic behaviour of the different parameters involved in this proof, we establish a sub-optimal version of the statement. Later on, this preliminary estimate will provide a link with the analysis of the pseudospectrum of the perturbations of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$.

From now on, we write $\tau=\operatorname{Re} z$ and $\delta=\operatorname{Im} z$, often without explicit mention.

4.1. Preliminary estimate. A direct application of the Schur Test gives the next preliminary version of Theorem 2.1.

Theorem 4.1. For $m>0$, let $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ be given by (2.3). Let $z=\tau+i \delta$ for $|\delta|<1$. Then,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \geq \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2} m \sqrt{1-\delta^{2}}}\left[\tau^{2}+\frac{m}{2} \tau+\frac{8\left(1+\delta^{2}\right)+4 m(1+\delta)-m^{2}}{8}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-1}\right)\right] \\
\text { and } \\
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{4}{m\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)}\left[\tau^{2}+\frac{1+\delta^{2}}{4}+m+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-2}\right)\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow+\infty$. Both limits inside the brackets converge uniformly ${ }^{2}$ for all $|\delta|<1$ and $m$ on compact set.
According to this statement, the resolvent norm of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ has leading asymptotic behaviour $|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}$, as $z \rightarrow \infty$ inside the band forming the numerical range. If we assume that Theorem 2.1 has already been proved, then we see that the leading order coefficient of the upper bound in (4.1) is optimal, up to a factor 4 . However, the leading coefficient of the lower bound is sub-optimal. The latter is a consequence of choosing below a sub-optimal pseudo-mode. We have included this calculation, in order to illustrate the construction of the optimal pseudo-mode for the full proof of the main Theorem 2.1 in the next subsection, without too many technical details.

Before proceeding to the asymptotic analysis of the coefficients involved, we highlight the connection with recent results of the same nature.

According to [15, Thm. 2.2], inside the numerical range the Schrödinger operator with a dislocated potential, $-\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}+i \operatorname{sgn}(x)$, has a resolvent norm with linear leading order of growth at infinity in $|\operatorname{Re} z|$. This discrepancy is explained by the fact that $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ is an operator of order 1, therefore the perturbation affects the resolvent by a higher order of magnitude.

When the potential is smooth and asymptotic to a dislocation, the effect of the perturbation on the Dirac operator appears to become substantially stronger. For instance, in the case of the operator $\overline{\mathscr{L}}=$ $\mathcal{D}_{m}+i \frac{2}{x} \arctan (x) I$, by using the recent results of [19, Thm. 3.11], it might be possible to show that there exists a WKB-pseudomode $\Psi_{\tau, n}$, such that

$$
\frac{\left\|(\overline{\mathscr{L}}-\tau I) \Psi_{\tau, n}\right\|}{\left\|\Psi_{\tau, n}\right\|}=\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-n}\right)
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. This maybe closely linked to the fact that interior singularities of a differential expression would create an exponential growth of the resolvent norm away from the spectrum. The phenomenon could be similar to the one reported recently in [3] for the case of a singular Sturm-Liouville operator and is worthy of further exploration.

We now give the proof of Theorem 4.1. We split the proof into 3 steps.
Step 1. The first step is an asymptotic analysis of the parameters involved in the resolvent estimate. This result is useful on its own, and will be invoked repeatedly in later sections.

Lemma 4.2. For $m>0$, let $\mu_{z}^{ \pm}$and $w_{z}^{ \pm}$be as in (3.3), and let $k_{z}$ be as in (3.19). For indices $p \in[[-4,2]]$ and parameters

$$
\mathrm{P} \in\left\{\mu_{z}^{ \pm}, \frac{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}}{1 \mp \delta}, w_{z}^{ \pm},\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|, k_{z}\right\}
$$

let the coefficients $C_{p}(\mathrm{P}) \in \mathbb{C}$ be prescribed in Table 1. There exists a constant $K_{m}>0$, independent of $\tau$ and $\delta$, such that

$$
\left|\mathrm{P}-\sum_{p=-4}^{2} C_{p}(\mathrm{P}) \tau^{p}\right| \leq \frac{K_{m}}{\tau^{5}}
$$

for all $|\tau| \geq 1$ and $|\delta|<1$. This constant can be replaced by a uniform constant for all $m$ on a compact set.
Proof. We only provide a proof sketch, because the details are lengthy routine calculations.
The strategy for each of the parameters $P$, is to find a suitable Taylor expansion from which the coefficients $C_{p} \in \mathbb{C}$ are obtained from those of the different powers of $\frac{1}{\tau}$. The remainder at power 5 in this expansion,

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ Here and elsewhere below, we adopt the common say that two function are related by $f(z)=g(z)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-p}\right)$ as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$ and that the limit converges uniformly for parameters satisfying a condition, iff there exist a constant $K>0$ independent of $\tau$ and these parameters, such that $|f(z)-g(z)| \leq K|\tau|^{-p}$ for all $|\tau| \geq 1$ and all such parameters satisfying the condition.

![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

gives the uniform bound in terms of $\delta$ and $m$. The specific Taylor series and coefficients are determined from the following reductions,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mu_{z}^{ \pm}=i \tau \sqrt{1-\frac{m^{2}+(1 \mp \delta)^{2}}{\tau^{2}} \mp i \frac{2(1 \mp \delta)}{\tau}} \quad \text { and } \\
& w_{z}^{ \pm}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{m \pm i(1 \mp \delta)}{\tau}}{1+\frac{m \mp i(1 \mp \delta)}{\tau}}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\mathrm{P}=\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|$, we use

$$
\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|=\sqrt{w_{z}^{ \pm} w_{2}^{ \pm}}=\sqrt{1+g(\tau)}
$$

where $g(\tau)=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\tau}\right)$ as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$. For $\mathrm{P}=k_{z}$, we use (3.19) and the expansions of $w_{ \pm}$.
Concretely, for $\mathrm{P}=\mu_{z}^{+}$, we write $\mu_{z}^{+}=i \tau f\left(\frac{1}{\tau}\right)$ where $f$ is analytic near 0 . Expanding in power series at that point, gives

$$
i \frac{f(x)}{x}=\sum_{k=-1}^{4} C_{-k}\left(\mu_{z}^{+}\right) x^{p}+\frac{x^{5}}{6!} \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)^{5} f^{(6)}(x s) \mathrm{d} s
$$

where the coefficients $C_{p}\left(\mu_{z}^{+}\right)$coincide with those in Table 1. Moreover, $f^{(6)}$ has a denominator involving a term of the form $\left(a(\delta, m) x^{2}+b(\delta, m) x+1\right)^{\frac{12}{12}}$ where $a$ and $b$ are bounded uniformly in both variables. Therefore, taking $|x|$ small enough, ensures that $\left|f^{(6)}(x)\right|$ is bounded uniformly in $x,|\delta|<1$ and $m>0$ in compact sets.

For the expansion of $\frac{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}}{1 \mp \delta}$, recall that $\operatorname{Re} \sqrt{\gamma}=\frac{|\operatorname{Im} \gamma|}{\sqrt{2(|\gamma|-\operatorname{Re} \gamma)}}$ for $\gamma \in \mathbb{C} \backslash \mathbb{R}$, and so

$$
\frac{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}}{1 \mp \delta}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{1-\frac{m^{2}+(1 \mp \delta)^{2}}{\tau^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(1-\frac{m^{2}+(1 \mp \delta)^{2}}{\tau^{2}}\right)^{2}+\frac{4(1 \mp \delta)^{2}}{\tau^{2}}}}}
$$

Step 2. Consider the upper bound first. According to Lemma 3.3, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| & \leq \frac{\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right) \max \left\{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|},\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\right\}}{\min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right\}} \\
& \leq\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right)\left(\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|}\right)\left(\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. By Lemma 4.2, the asymptotic behaviour of each of the multiplying terms above is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|k_{z}\right|+1 & =\frac{1}{m} \tau^{2}+\left(\frac{1+\delta^{2}}{m}-m+1\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right) \\
\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|} & =2+m^{2} \tau^{-2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right) \\
\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}} & =\frac{1}{1-\delta^{2}}\left[2-m^{2} \tau^{-2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$. Note that the first two coefficients of the terms involving the maximum above are identical.
