Multiplying and collecting terms, gives the upper bound in (4.1) as required. Observe that the fact that the limit inside the bracket is uniform in the parameters, carries over from the conclusion of Lemma 4.2.

Step 3. Now consider the lower estimate of the resolvent in (4.1). Set a pseudo-mode

$$
\psi_{0}(x)=\binom{1}{w_{2}^{+} } e^{\mu_{2}^{+} x} \chi(-\infty, 0)(x)
$$

which belongs to $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ and has a norm $\left\|\psi_{0}\right\|=\frac{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{x}^{-}\right|^{2}}}{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{-}}}$. From the formula of the kernel in (3.5) and considering the location of the support of $\psi_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1} \psi_{0}\right\|^{2} & \geq \int_{0}^{+\infty}\left|\int_{-\infty}^{0} N_{3, z}\left(\frac{1}{w_{x}^{+}}\right) e^{-\mu_{x}^{+} x+2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{x}^{-} y} \mathrm{~d} y\right|_{C^{2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\left|N_{3, z}\left(\frac{1}{w_{2}^{+}}\right)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} ^{2} \frac{1}{8\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)^{2} \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}} \\
& =\left(\frac{\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right) \sqrt{1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}}}{\left|w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right|}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{8\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)^{2} \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| & \geq \frac{\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1} \psi_{0}\right\|}{\left\|\psi_{0}\right\|} \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)}{\operatorname{Re}\left(\mu_{z}^{-}\right) \operatorname{Re}\left(\mu_{z}^{+}\right)}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\left|w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right|^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

According to Lemma 4.2, the first bracket is $\mathcal{O}(1)$ and the second term is $\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{2}\right)$. Multiplying and collecting coefficients, gives the lower estimate of the resolvent in (4.1). We omit further details, but this confirms the validity of Theorem 4.1.
4.2. Proof of Theorem 2.1. We now establish improved estimates, which enable identifying the sharp constants for the resolvent norm asymptotic of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ in the instability band. These will render Theorem 2.1 as a corollary. The strategy for the computation of the different constants has two parts. We first split the resolvent as the sum of two integral operators,

$$
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z I\right)^{-1}=T_{1}(z)+T_{2}(z)
$$

where the norm of the operator $T_{1}(z)$ carries the leading order behaviour and $\left\|T_{2}(z)\right\|$ is $\mathcal{O}(1)$ at infinity. We then proceed as in the proof of Theorem 4.1, and compute the asymptotic coefficients of $\left\|T_{1}(z)\right\|$ and $\left\|T_{2}(z)\right\|$. In the case of the lower bound, we find a pseudo-mode for $T_{1}(z)$ that is sharp for the leading order, by optimising the contribution of the two components of the wave function in an adaptive manner as $z$ moves towards infinity. For a further discussion on the computation of other coefficients see Remark 4.6 at the end of this section.

The explicit formulas of the two integral operators is the following. For $j=1,2$,

$$
T_{j}(z) f(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} \mathcal{R}_{j, z}(x, y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

where,

$$
\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)= \begin{cases}N_{1, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x+y)}, & \text { for }\{y<x<0\} \\ N_{3, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} x+\mu_{z}^{-} y}, & \text { for }\{y<0<x\} \\ N_{4, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x+y)}, & \text { for }\{0<y<x\} \\ N_{7, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x+y)}, & \text { for }\{0<x<y\} \\ N_{8, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-} x-\mu_{z}^{+} y}, & \text { for }\{x<0<y\} \\ N_{10, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x+y)}, & \text { for }\{x<y<0\}\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{R}_{2, z}(x, y)= \begin{cases}N_{2, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)}, & \text { for }\{y<x<0\} \\ 0, & \text { for }\{y<0<x\} \\ N_{5, z} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}, & \text { for }\{0<y<x\} \\ N_{6, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{+}(x-y)}, & \text { for }\{0<x<y\} \\ 0, & \text { for }\{x<0<y\} \\ N_{9, z} e^{\mu_{z}^{-}(x-y)}, & \text { for }\{x<y<0\}\end{cases}
$$

Recall the definition of the matrices $N_{k, z}$ at the beginning of Section 3.

A crucial reason for the split of the resolvent in this fashion is to observe that the term $\frac{1}{w_{s}^{+}+w_{s}^{-}}$is the only one responsible for the quadratic growth of the norm and that this term appears only in $N_{k, z}$ for $k \in\{1,3,4,7,8,10\}$. Moreover, now the kernel $\mathcal{R}_{1, z}$ is separable, therefore a sharp upper bound on its norm is obtained by means of Hölder's Inequality.

For $j \in[[1,10]]$, we denote $n_{j}=n_{j}(z)=\left|N_{j, z}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}$. The fact that $\operatorname{det} N_{j, z}=0$ and substitution give

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
n_{1}=n_{10}=\frac{1}{2}\left|\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{+}+w_{s}^{-}}\right|\left(\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|}\right), & n_{2}=n_{9}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|}\right) \\
n_{3}=n_{8}=\frac{\sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|w_{s}^{+}+w_{s}^{-}\right|}, & n_{4}=n_{7}=\frac{1}{2}\left|\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{+}+w_{s}^{-}}\right|\left(\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|}\right) \\
n_{5}=n_{6}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|}\right) . &
\end{array}
$$

Note that the asymptotic of all the terms in the formulas for $n_{j}$ are available from the calculations performed in the previous subsection. Also note that the operator norms of $\mathcal{R}_{j, z}$ are symmetric with respect to the axis $y=x$, as was the case for $\mathcal{R}_{z}$.

The next proposition gives explicit bounds for the norm of the leading operator $T_{1}(z)$. The match of all terms in these bounds except $\widetilde{B}_{z}$ and $B_{z}$ is the main ingredient that enables the sharp constants below. For $z \neq 0$, we write

$$
\operatorname{csgn}(z)=\frac{z}{|z|}
$$

Proposition 4.3. Let $m>0$. Let the operator $T_{1}(z)$ be as in (4.4)-(4.5). For all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$, let

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A_{z}=\frac{n_{1}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)^{2}}, \quad C_{z}=\frac{n_{4}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)^{2}}, \quad D_{z}=\frac{n_{3}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)} \\
& B_{z}=\frac{n_{3}}{2 \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)}}\left(\frac{n_{1}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{n_{4}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right) \\
& \widetilde{B}_{z}=\frac{n_{3}}{2 \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)}}\left(\frac{n_{1} \operatorname{Re}\left(\frac{\operatorname{csgn}\left(\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{-}}\right)}{w_{s}^{+}}\right)}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}-\frac{n_{4} \operatorname{Re}\left(\frac{\operatorname{csgn}\left(\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{+}}\right)}{w_{s}^{+}}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, $T_{1}(z)$ is bounded for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|T_{1}(z)\right\| & \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sqrt{\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+B_{z}^{2}}+A_{z}+C_{z}+2 D_{z}} \\
& \text { and } \\
\left\|T_{1}(z)\right\| & \geq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sqrt{\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+\widetilde{B}_{z}^{2}}+A_{z}+C_{z}+2 D_{z}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Upper bound. Let $\Psi \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ be such that $\|\Psi\|^{2}=1$. Then,

$$
\left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi\right\|^{2} \leq \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}|\Psi(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

The right-hand side of this expression is given explicitly as follows,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}|\Psi(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =\frac{1}{2\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)}\left(n_{1} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right) y}|\Psi(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y+n_{8} \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right) y}|\Psi(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y\right)^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{2\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)}\left(n_{3} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right) y}|\Psi(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y+n_{4} \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right) y}|\Psi(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

By applying Holder's Inequality to the inner integrals, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi\right\|^{2} \leq \frac{1}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}\left(\frac{n_{1}}{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}\right)}+\frac{n_{8}}{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}\right)^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\left(\frac{n_{3}}{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}\right)}+\frac{n_{4}}{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}\right)^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{n_{1}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)^{2}}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}\right)}^{2}+\frac{n_{4}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)^{2}}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}^{2}+\frac{n_{3}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)} \\
& +\frac{n_{3}}{2 \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)}}\left(\frac{n_{1}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{n_{4}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right)\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}\right)}\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we have used that $n_{1}=n_{10}, n_{3}=n_{8}$ and that $\|\Psi\|=1$.
Now, for constants $A, B, C \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\max _{x^{2}+y^{2}=1} A x^{2}+B x y+C y^{2}=\frac{A+C+\sqrt{(A-C)^{2}+B^{2}}}{2}
$$

Then, taking $x=\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{-}\right)}$and $y=\|\Psi\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}$, we obtain that, for all $\Psi \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ such that $\|\Psi\|^{2}=1$,

$$
\left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi\right\|^{2} \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(A_{z}+C_{z}+\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+B_{z}^{2}}+2 D_{z}\right)
$$

where $A_{z}, B_{z}, C_{z}, D_{z}$ are as above. Moreover, since all these 4 terms are finite for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$, then indeed $T_{1}(z)$ is a bounded operator.
Lower bound. In order to obtain the lower bound estimate on the norm of $T_{1}(z)$, consider a pseudo-mode of the form

$$
\Psi_{0}(y)= \begin{cases}\beta\left(\begin{array}{l}
-1 \\
w_{z}^{-}
\end{array}\right) e^{-\overline{\mu_{z}^{+} y}} & \text { if } y \geq 0 \\
\alpha\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
w_{z}^{+}
\end{array}\right) e^{\overline{\mu_{z}^{-} y}} & \text { if } y \leq 0\end{cases}
$$

where $\alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{R}$ will be chosen later to normalise $\left\|\Psi_{0}\right\|$ and maximise $\left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi_{0}\right\|$.
We first compute the square of $\left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi_{0}\right\|$. Indeed,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi_{0}\right\|^{2} & =\int_{-\infty}^{0}\left|\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y) \Psi_{0}(y) \mathrm{d} y\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x+\int_{0}^{+\infty}\left|\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y) \Psi_{0}(y) \mathrm{d} y\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& =: K_{1}+K_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

By the definition of $\Psi_{0}$, we have,

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y) \Psi_{0}(y) \mathrm{d} y=e^{\mu_{z}^{+} x}\left[\frac{\alpha \frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right) \frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}}}{4 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}+\frac{\frac{\beta\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right]\left(\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}}\right) \quad \text { for } x<0
$$

and

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y) \Psi_{0}(y) \mathrm{d} y=e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} x}\left[\frac{\frac{\alpha\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right) \frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}}}{4 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}+\frac{\beta \frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}\right) \frac{-1}{w_{z}^{+}}}{4 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right]\left(\frac{-1}{w_{z}^{+}}\right) \quad \text { for } x>0
$$

Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{1}= & \frac{1}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}\left[\frac{\left|\alpha\right|^{2} n_{1}^{2}\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)^{2}}+\frac{\left|\beta\right|^{2} n_{8}^{2}\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)^{2}}\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{n_{1} n_{8} \alpha \beta \sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)}}{2\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right)} \operatorname{Re}\left(\operatorname{cogn}\left(\frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{-}}\right)\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{2}= & \frac{1}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}}\left[\frac{\left|\alpha\left|{ }^{2} n_{3}^{2}\left(1+\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)\right.}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}\right)^{2}}+\frac{|\beta|^{2} n_{4}^{2}\left(1+\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}\right)^{2}}\right. \\
& \left.-\frac{n_{3} n_{4} \alpha \beta \sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)}}{2\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}\right)} \operatorname{Re}\left(\operatorname{cogn}\left(\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{+}}\right)\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover,

$$
\left\|\Psi_{0}\right\|^{2}=|\alpha|^{2} \frac{1+\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|^{2}}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}+|\beta|^{2} \frac{1+\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|^{2}}{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}}
$$

To normalise $\Psi_{0}$ properly, we re-write $\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}}{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{s}^{-}\right|^{2}}} x$ and $\beta=\frac{\sqrt{2 \operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}}}{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{s}^{+}\right|^{2}}} y$, for $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $x^{2}+y^{2}=1$. We seek for pairs $(x, y)$, such that the expression

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi_{0}\right\|^{2} \\
= & \frac{n_{1}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}\right)^{2}} x^{2}+\frac{n_{4}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}\right)^{2}} y^{2}+\frac{n_{3}^{2}}{4\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}\right)} \\
& +\frac{n_{3}}{2 \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}\right)\left(\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}\right)}}\left(\frac{n_{1} \operatorname{Re}\left(\operatorname{cogn}\left(\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{-}}\right)\right)}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}-\frac{n_{4} \operatorname{Re}\left(\operatorname{cogn}\left(\frac{w_{s}^{+}-w_{s}^{-}}{w_{s}^{+}}\right)\right)}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}}\right) x y
\end{aligned}
$$

attains its maximum. Therefore, according to (4.10) once again, we have

$$
\left\|T_{1}(z)\right\|^{2} \geq\left\|T_{1}(z) \Psi_{0}\right\|^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(A_{z}+C_{z}+\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+\widetilde{B}_{z}^{2}}+2 D_{z}\right)
$$

Thus, the lower bound of $T_{1}(z)$ is indeed confirmed.
Our next goal is to determine an upper bound for the norm of $T_{2}(z)$.
Proposition 4.4. Let $m>0$. Let the operator $T_{2}(z)$ be as in (4.4)-(4.6). Then, $T_{2}(z)$ is bounded for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. Moreover,

$$
\left\|T_{2}(z)\right\| \leq \max \left\{\frac{n_{2}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}, \frac{n_{5}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}}\right\}
$$

Proof. We use the Schur Test to prove this proposition. For $x<0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{2, z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} y & =\int_{-\infty}^{x} n_{2} e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}(x-y)} \mathrm{d} y+\int_{x}^{0} n_{9} e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}(x-y)} \mathrm{d} y \\
& =\frac{n_{2}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}\left(2-e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}x}\right) \leq \frac{n_{2}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $n_{2}=n_{9}$. Similarly, for $x \geq 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{2, z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} y & =\int_{0}^{x} n_{5} e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}(x-y)} \mathrm{d} y+\int_{x}^{+\infty} n_{6} e^{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}(x-y)} \mathrm{d} y \\
& =\frac{n_{5}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{-}}\left(2-e^{-\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}x}\right) \leq \frac{n_{5}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{s}^{+}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $n_{5}=n_{6}$. Now recall that $\left|\mathcal{R}_{2, z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}=\left|\mathcal{R}_{2, z}(y, x)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}$. Hence, by virtue of the Schur Test, the claimed conclusion follows.

With the bounds for the norms of the components $T_{j}(z)$ at hand from the previous two propositions, we are now in the position to tackle Theorem 2.1. This will be a direct consequence of the following theorem, which gives slightly more refined asymptotic estimates. This theorem is one of the main contributions of this paper and it directly implies Theorem 2.1.

Theorem 4.5. For $m>0$, let $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ be the dislocated Dirac operator (2.3). Let $z=\tau+i \delta$ for $|\delta|<1$. Then, as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{1}{m\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)}\left[\tau^{2}+\mathrm{P}_{0}^{+}+\mathrm{P}_{-2}^{+} \tau^{-2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right] \\
\text { and } \\
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \geq \frac{1}{m\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)}\left[\tau^{2}+\mathrm{P}_{0}^{-}+\mathrm{P}_{-2}^{-} \tau^{-2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

where

$$
\mathrm{P}_{0}^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{4}\left(3+2 \delta^{2}-2 m^{2}\right) \pm 2 m, \quad \mathrm{P}_{-2}^{+}=\frac{1}{4}\left(3 m^{2}+\delta^{2}\left(9 m^{2}-8\right)\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathrm{P}_{-2}^{-}=\frac{1}{8}\left(5 m^{2}+\delta^{2}\left(19 m^{2}-16\right)\right)
$$

The limits inside the brackets converge uniformly for all $|\delta|<1$ and $m$ on compact sets.
The remainder of this subsection is devoted to sketching the proof of this theorem. That involves computing the coefficients in the asymptotic expansions of the various terms in the expressions (4.8). We only give the intermediate results in the computation of these coefficients.

Coefficients for $\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}$. We take the square of the following.

$$
A_{z}-C_{z}=\frac{-\delta}{m^{2}\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\sum_{k=-4}^{4} \mathrm{P}_{k} \tau^{k}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-6}\right)\right]
$$

were $^{3}$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{P}_{4}=1, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=2\left(\delta^{2}-m^{2}+1\right), \quad \mathrm{P}_{0}=\delta^{4}+2 \delta^{2}\left(m^{2}-1\right)+m^{4}+1 \\
\mathrm{P}_{-2}=-2\left(\delta^{4}+6 \delta^{2}+1\right) m^{2}, \quad \mathrm{P}_{-4}=m^{2}\left(2 \delta^{6}-5 \delta^{4}\left(m^{2}-6\right)-\delta^{2}\left(22 m^{2}-30\right)-6 m^{2}+2\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Coefficients for $B_{z}^{2}$. We use

$$
B_{z}^{2}=D_{z}\left(\frac{n_{3}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{n_{4}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right)^{2}
$$

together with the following. On the one hand,

$$
D_{z}=\frac{1}{m^{2}\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)}\left[\sum_{k=-4}^{4} \mathrm{P}_{k} \tau^{k}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-6}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{P}_{4}=\frac{1}{4}, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\delta^{2}-m^{2}+1\right), \quad \mathrm{P}_{0}=\frac{1}{4}\left(\delta^{4}+\delta^{2}\left(m^{2}-2\right)+m^{4}+1\right) \\
& \mathrm{P}_{-2}=-4 \delta^{2} m^{2}, \quad \mathrm{P}_{-4}=-\frac{1}{4}\left(m^{2}\left(\delta^{4}\left(m^{2}-32\right)+\delta^{2}\left(31 m^{2}-32\right)+m^{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\left(\frac{n_{3}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{n_{4}}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{m^{2}\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\sum_{k=-4}^{4} \mathrm{P}_{k} \tau^{k}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-6}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{P}_{4}=4, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=8\left(\delta^{2}-m^{2}+1\right), \quad \mathrm{P}_{0}=4\left(\delta^{4}+\delta^{2}\left(3 m^{2}-2\right)+m^{4}-m^{2}+1\right) \\
\mathrm{P}_{-2}=-16 \delta^{2}\left(\delta^{2}+3\right) m^{2}, \quad \mathrm{P}_{-4}=-4 m^{2}\left(-4 \delta^{6}+8 \delta^{4}\left(m^{2}-5\right)+5 \delta^{2}\left(5 m^{2}-4\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Coefficients for $\sqrt{\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+B_{z}^{2}}+A_{z}+C_{z}+2 D_{z}}$. We use the following,

$$
A_{z}+C_{z}+2 D_{z}=\frac{1}{m^{2}\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\sum_{k=-2}^{4} \mathrm{P}_{k} \tau^{k}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{P}_{4}=1, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=2\left(\delta^{2}-m^{2}+1\right) \\
\mathrm{P}_{0}=\frac{1}{2}\left(2 \delta^{4}+\delta^{2}\left(5 m^{2}-4\right)+2 m^{4}-m^{2}+2\right), \quad \mathrm{P}_{-2}=-16 \delta^{2} m^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+B_{z}^{2}}=\frac{1}{m^{2}\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\sum_{k=-2}^{4} \mathrm{P}_{k} \tau_{k}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{P}_{4}=1, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=2\left(\delta^{2}-m^{2}+1\right) \\
\mathrm{P}_{0}=\frac{1}{2}\left(2 \delta^{4}+\delta^{2}\left(5 m^{2}-4\right)+2 m^{4}-m^{2}+2\right), \quad \mathrm{P}_{-2}=-256 \delta^{2} m^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ Here and henceforth, $\mathrm{P}_{k}=0$ for $k$ odd.

Note that the first 3 coefficients of these two terms match exactly. This gives,

$$
\left\|T_{1}(z)\right\| \leq \frac{1}{m\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)}\left[\tau^{2}+\mathrm{P}_{0}+\mathrm{P}_{-2} \tau^{-2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\mathrm{P}_{0}=\frac{1}{4}\left(3+2 \delta^{2}-2 m^{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathrm{P}_{-2}=\frac{1}{4}\left(3 m^{2}+\delta^{2}\left(9 m^{2}-8\right)\right)
$$

Coefficients for $\sqrt{\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+\widetilde{B}_{z}^{2}+A_{z}+C_{z}+2 D_{z}}}$. We use the fact that

$$
\operatorname{Re}(\operatorname{cogn}(z))=\frac{\operatorname{Re} z}{|z|}
$$

to obtain the asymptotic

$$
\operatorname{Re}\left(\operatorname{cogn} \frac{w_{z}^{+}-w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{2}}\right)=\mp 1 \pm \frac{m^{2}}{2 \tau^{4}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-6}\right)
$$

Hence we get

$$
\sqrt{\left(A_{z}-C_{z}\right)^{2}+\widetilde{B}_{z}^{2}}=\frac{1}{m^{2}\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[\sum_{k=-2}^{4} \mathrm{P}_{k} \tau_{k}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{P}_{4}=1, \quad \mathrm{P}_{2}=2\left(\delta^{2}-m^{2}+1\right) \\
\mathrm{P}_{0}=\delta^{4}+\delta^{2}\left(3 m^{2}-2\right)+m^{4}-m^{2}+1, \quad \mathrm{P}_{-2}=-32 \delta^{2}\left(\delta^{2}+7\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Note that only the two final coefficients are different from the ones of $B_{z}^{2}$. Hence

$$
\left\|T_{1}(z)\right\| \geq \frac{1}{m\left(1-\delta^{2}\right)}\left[\tau^{2}+\mathrm{P}_{0}+\widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{-2} \tau^{-2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right]
$$

where

$$
\mathrm{P}_{0}=\frac{1}{4}\left(3+2 \delta^{2}-2 m^{2}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \widetilde{\mathrm{P}}_{-2}=\frac{1}{8}\left(5 m^{2}+\delta^{2}\left(19 m^{2}-16\right)\right)
$$

Completion of the proof. According to (4.2)-(4.3), we have

$$
\left\|T_{2}(z)\right\| \leq\left(n_{2}+n_{5}\right)\left(\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}}+\frac{1}{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}}\right)=\frac{1}{1-\delta^{2}}\left(2+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{-4}\right)\right)
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$. Thus, we complete the proof of Theorem 4.5, by combining the asymptotic formulas (4.14)(4.15) with this and invoking the triangle inequality.

Remark 4.6. We suspect that with some more effort, it is possible to show that there exists $\mathrm{P}_{0}$ such that

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\|=\frac{1}{1-|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{m}|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m}\left[|\operatorname{Im} z|^{2}+\mathrm{P}_{0}\right]+\mathcal{O}\left(|\operatorname{Re} z|^{-2}\right)\right)
$$

where $\mathrm{P}_{0}$ is a constant independent of $z$ such that

$$
\left|\mathrm{P}_{0}\right| \leq \frac{3}{2}+4 m+m^{2}
$$

Note that the only point left to show here is that the coefficient $\mathrm{P}_{0}$ actually exists. The bound on its magnitude follows directly from our Theorem 4.5. Two comments on this are in place.

- To prove this claim, one possibility is to find sharp lower bounds for $\left\|T_{2}(z)\right\|$, then feed into the final step above. This might not be easy and a more refined construction of pseudomodes seems to be needed.
- To confirm existence of $\mathrm{P}_{0}$ without control on $\left\|T_{2}(z)\right\|$, perhaps it is possible to begin by proving that the function

$$
s_{1}(\tau, \delta)=\frac{1}{\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-\tau-i \delta\right)^{-1}\right\|}
$$

being the first singular value of the operator $\mathscr{L}_{m}-\tau-i \delta$, is real analytic in the variables $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\delta \in(-1,1)$. This might follow from the fact that $\mathscr{L}_{m}-z$ is an integral operator with coefficients analytic in $z$, but it is not automatic and an analysis of its multiplicity is required.

# 5. Perturbations of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ by a long-range potential 

We now consider perturbations of the form $\mathscr{L}_{m}+V$ where $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$. To aid the reader through this section, we recall the hypotheses,

H2: $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<1$,
H3: $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right) \cap L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ for some $p \in(1, \infty]$.
Either will be assumed throughout.
Our main goal in the first part of the section is to identify a closed extension, $\mathscr{L}_{m, V} \supseteq \mathscr{L}_{m}+V$, which is well defined under either assumptions and preserves the essential spectra. Then, in the second part, we examine the spectrum and pseudospectrum of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ inside the instability band, $\Sigma=\{|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\}$.

Subsection 5.2 is devoted to the proof of the main Theorem 2.5 about the localisation of the point spectrum for $m>0$. Subsection 5.3 addresses confirmation that there can be potentials with infinitely many eigenvalues in the instability band. Subsection 5.4 discusses the effect of weak coupling, when imposing further concrete hypotheses on the decay and regularity of $V$, and comprises the proof of Theorem 2.7. Finally the proof of Theorem 2.4 about the pseudospectrum is given in Subsection 5.5.
5.1. Proof of Proposition 2.3. In order to show the existence of the closed extension $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$, and determine its spectrum and pseudospectrum, our main tool is the Birman-Schwinger-type principle formulated in [13]. We quote that result in Theorem A. 1 and apply it as follows.

Set the Hilbert spaces $\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{X}=L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. Set the unperturbed operator $H_{0}=\mathscr{L}_{m}$. The auxiliary factors $A$ and $B$ take the following form. Write

$$
V(x)=U(x)|V(x)|
$$

in polar form, where $U(x)$ is the partial isometry and $|V(x)|=\left(V^{*}(x) V(x)\right)^{1 / 2}$. We set

$$
A(x)=|V(x)|^{1 / 2} \quad \text { and } \quad B(x)=U(x)|V(x)|^{1 / 2}
$$

Then, we have

$$
|A(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2} \times \mathbb{C}^{2}}=|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2} \times \mathbb{C}^{2}}^{1 / 2}=|B(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2} \times \mathbb{C}^{2}}
$$

The first equality follows from the property that the norm of the square root of a matrix equals the square root of the norm of the matrix itself. To establish the second equality in (5.2), observe that $\operatorname{Ker}(|V(x)|) \subset$ $\operatorname{Ker}\left(|V(x)|^{1 / 2}\right)$. Consequently, we have $\overline{\operatorname{Im}\left(|V(x)|^{1 / 2}\right)} \subset[\operatorname{Ker}(U(x))]^{\perp}$, because $\operatorname{Ker}(|V(x)|)=\operatorname{Ker}(U(x))$, cf. [5, Prop. 2.85]). Hence, as $U(x)$ is a partial isometry, it follows that

$$
|B(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2} \times \mathbb{C}^{2}}=\sup _{|v|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}=1}}|U(x)| V(x)|^{1 / 2} v|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}=\sup _{|v|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}=1}}| | V(x)|^{1 / 2} v|_{\mathbb{C}^{2}}=|A(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2} \times \mathbb{C}^{2}}=|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2} \times \mathbb{C}^{2}}^{1 / 2}
$$

The operators $A$ and $B$ denote the multiplication operators

$$
A f(x)=A(x) f(x) \quad \text { and } \quad B f(x)=B(x) f(x)
$$

with their maximal domains. By construction, they are both closed and densely defined. For each $z \in$ $\rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$, let

$$
R_{0}(z)=\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1} \quad \text { and } \quad Q(z)=\overline{A R_{0}(z) B}
$$

This settles the framework of Theorem A.1.
Now we give the proof of Proposition 2.3. We split it into three steps. In the first step we verify that the hypotheses (B1) and (B2) of Theorem A. 1 hold, for all $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$. In the second step we verify that (B3) is implied by either of the two different assumptions, H2 or H3. In the final step we derive the claims made about the spectrum.
Step 1: conditions (B1) and (B2). Let $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$. Our goal is to show that, for suitable $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$,
(B1) the operator $R_{0}(z) B$ is closable, and both $A R_{0}(z)$ and $\overline{R_{0}(z) B}$ are bounded;
(B2) the operator $A R_{0}(z) B$ has a bounded closure $Q(z)=\overline{A R_{0}(z) B}$.
Firstly, note that the Schur Test conditions,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left[\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right]_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{n} \mathrm{~d} y \leq K_{n}(z), & \text { for a.e. } x \in \mathbb{R} \\
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left[\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right]_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{n} \mathrm{~d} x \leq K_{n}(z), & \text { for a.e. } y \in \mathbb{R}
\end{array}
$$

holds for all fixed $n \in \mathbb{N}$. The proof of this is the same as for the case of the power $n=1$, addressed in the verification of (3.23), as the integration only involves exponential functions. Here

$$
K_{n}(z)=\frac{2}{n \min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}\right\}}\left(\sup _{t \in \mathbb{R}} \varphi_{z}(t)\right)^{n}
$$

$\varphi_{z}$ is as in (3.18) and $K_{n}(z)$ is finite for each $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$.
Now, since $H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \subset L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ and $|V|^{\frac{1}{2}} \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, it follows that $H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \subset \operatorname{Dom}(A)$. Given that

$$
R_{0}(z): L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \longrightarrow H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)
$$

we have $\operatorname{Dom}\left(A R_{0}(z)\right)=L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$. Therefore, $A R_{0}(z)$ is closed and hence bounded by the Closed Graph Theorem. This confirms the second requirement in (B1). Moreover, $A R_{0}(z)$ is a Hilbert-Schmidt operator. Indeed, from (5.2) and (5.3) with $n=2$, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}|A(x) \mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y & \leq \int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \\
& \leq K_{2}(z)\|V\|_{L^{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, we also have

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left[\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y) B(y)\right]_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \leq K_{2}(z)\|V\|_{L^{1}}
$$

and thus the integral operator

$$
f(\cdot) \longmapsto \int_{\mathbb{R}} \mathcal{R}_{z}(\cdot, y) B(y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

is Hilbert-Schmidt. But the latter is an extension of the operator $R_{0}(z) B$, thus $R_{0}(z) B$ is closable. Furthermore, since the domain $\operatorname{Dom}\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)=\operatorname{Dom}(B)$ is dense in $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R} ; \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ and the integral operator above is continuous, $\overline{R_{0}(z) B}$ coincides with it. This completes the confirmation of (B1).

Now, we address (B2). Once again we appeal to the Schur Test, in order to show that $A R_{0}(z) B$ has a bounded closure. But now we consider the weight,

$$
p(x)= \begin{cases}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{1 / 2} & \text { if }|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}>0 \\ 1 & \text { if }|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}=0\end{cases}
$$

According to (5.2), for almost every $x \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}|A(x) \mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y) B(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} p(y) \mathrm{d} y & \leq p(x) \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} p(y)^{2} \mathrm{~d} y \\
& =p(x) \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}|V(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

and, for almost every $y \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}|A(x) \mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y) B(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} p(x) \mathrm{d} x \leq p(y) \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

Since $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$ and $\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(\cdot, \cdot)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ (recall Lemma 3.2), then by the Schur Test, the integral operator

$$
f(\cdot) \longmapsto \int_{\mathbb{R}} A(\cdot) \mathcal{R}_{z}(\cdot, y) B(y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

is bounded. Thus, since $H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right) \subset \operatorname{Dom}(A), \operatorname{Dom}\left(A R_{0}(z) B\right)=\operatorname{Dom}(B)$, and since $\operatorname{Dom}(B)$ is dense, continuity implies that $Q(z)$ is equal to this integral operator. Moreover,

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq \sup _{y \in \mathbb{R}} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

This ensures the validity of (B2).
Step 2: hypothesis (B3) and existence of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$. We now need to verify that
(B3) $\left\{z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right):-1 \in \rho(Q(z))\right\} \neq \varnothing$.
We split the proof into the two sub-cases depending on the hypothesis on $V$.
First, assume that $\mathbf{H} \mathbf{2}$ is the one condition that holds. According to (5.6), (3.20) and (3.21), for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$,

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}} \sup _{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right| \leq \frac{\|V\|_{L^{1}}}{2}\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right) \max \left\{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|}\right\}
$$

From (3.3) and (3.19), it follows that $w_{i \delta}^{ \pm} \rightarrow-i$ and $k_{i \delta} \rightarrow 0$ as $\delta \rightarrow \infty$. Thus, the terms inside the maximum become close to 2 as $\delta \rightarrow \infty$. Since $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<1$, then indeed (B3) follows taking $z$ on the imaginary axis with sufficiently large modulus.

Now, if instead condition H3 holds for $p \in(1, \infty]$, by Holder's inequality and (5.3), we get

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq\|V(x)\|_{L^{p}}\left(K_{q}(z)\right)^{1 / q}, \quad \frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=1
$$

Therefore, a similar argument as the previous sub-case, yields $K_{q}(z) \rightarrow 0$ for $z$ on the imaginary axis with sufficiently large modulus. Hence, (B3) is also valid under assumption H3.

As a conclusion to this step we now have that, by virtue of the first part of Theorem A.1, a closed extension $\mathscr{L}_{m, V} \supseteq \mathscr{L}_{m}+V$ indeed exists and

$$
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}-z\right)^{-1}=R_{0}(z)-\overline{R_{0}(z) B}(I+Q(z))^{-1} A R_{0}(z)
$$

for all $z$ such that $-1 \in \rho(Q(z))$. Note that, under the hypotheses, the latter is non-empty.

Step 3: conclusions 1) -4) of the proposition. The crucial point in the proof is to observe that $A R_{0}(z)$ and $\overline{R_{0}(z) B}$ are Hilbert-Schmidt operators, therefore the difference

$$
\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}-\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}-z\right)^{-1}=\overline{R_{0}(z) B}(I+Q(z))^{-1} A R_{0}(z)
$$

is compact. The stability of the first four essential spectra follows directly from [12, Thm. IX.2.4]. Moreover, when $m>0, \mathbb{C} \backslash \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 1}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}\right)$ has one connected component, then $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{e} 5}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}\right)$ in that case is also identical to the other essential spectra, cf. [20, Prop. 5.5.4]. This confirms the conclusions 1) and 2).

The rest of the proof assumes that $m=0$. In that case, notice that $k_{z}=0$ and $\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|=1$. For 3), observe that by direct substitution into (5.7), we have that, if $V$ satisfies $\mathbf{H 2}$, then $\|Q(z)\| \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}}<1$ for all

$$
z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=\mathbb{C} \backslash\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z| \leq 1\}
$$

Hence $-1 \in \rho(Q(z))$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$ such that $|\operatorname{Im} z|>1$. That is, any eigenvalue of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ should all be located in the strip $\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z \leq 1\}$ as claimed.

Finally, for 4), if $V$ satisfies $\mathbf{H 3}$ instead, the estimate (5.8), the fact that

$$
\min \left\{\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{+}, \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{-}\right\}=|\operatorname{Im} z|-1 \quad \text { for } \quad|\operatorname{Im} z|>1
$$

and that $\varphi_{z}(t)=1$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}$, ensure that

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq\|V\|_{L^{p}}\left(\frac{2}{q(|\operatorname{Im} z|-1)}\right)^{1 / q}, \quad q=\frac{p}{p-1}
$$

for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|>1\}$. Hence, for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$ such that $|\operatorname{Im} z|>1+\frac{2}{q}\|V\|_{L^{p}}^{q}$, the right-hand side is strictly smaller than 1 . This gives 4) for $p<\infty$. For the case $p=\infty$, note that $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0, V}\right) \subset$ $\operatorname{Spec}_{\|V\|_{\infty}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{0}\right)$ (from the second equality in (1.3)). This completes the proof of Proposition 2.3.

For later purposes, note that the operator $Q(z)$ is also Hilbert-Schmidt. Indeed, the identities (5.2), (3.20) and (3.21), yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}|A(x) \mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y) B(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{2} \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \\
& \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{2} \sup _{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}}\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{2}}{4} \max \left\{\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right)^{2}\left(\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|}\right)^{2},\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right)^{2}\left(\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\right)^{2}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the right-hand side is finite for each $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$.
We close this subsection with a remark that provides the context of our findings about perturbations of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ by long-range potentials.

Remark 5.1. In the case of long-range perturbations of the dislocated Schrödinger operator $-\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}}{\mathrm{~d} x^{2}}+i \operatorname{sgn}(x)$, considered in [15, Subsec. 5.1], the condition $V \in L^{1}(\mathbb{R})$ alone gives the existence of a closed extension directly, via the associated quadratic forms. The distinction with the present case and the need for the condition $\mathbf{H} \mathbf{2}$ can be explained through the behaviour of the resolvent kernel, as follows.

The estimates around [15, Est. (5.6)], ensure that the $L^{\infty}$ norm of the kernel of the unperturbed resolvent for the Schrödinger model decays to zero as $z \rightarrow \infty$ along the imaginary axis. By contrast, the kernel $\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)$ in the present case does not have a decaying $L^{\infty}$ norm. Effectively, the right-hand sides in (3.20) and (3.21) do not decay to zero. Note that this is analogous to the contrast between the free Schrödinger kernel and the free particle Dirac kernel. For details, see [8, Form. (13)-(14)].

5.2. Proof of Theorem 2.5. The Proposition 2.3, which has been already proven, provides a general statement about exclusion regions (semi-planes) for the eigenvalues of $\mathscr{L}_{0, V}$. We now proceed to give the proof of the first main result of this section, Theorem 2.5. This theorem, in a similar vein, describes regions of exclusion for the eigenvalues of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ in the case $m>0$. Thus, for the remainder of this subsection, we assume that $m \neq 0$.

Our main arguments involve deriving upper bound for the norm of the Birman-Schwinger operator, $Q(z)$, introduced in (5.6). To achieve this, we give sharp estimates on the matrix norm of the kernel in various regions of the complex $z$-plane. Specifically, we partition the resolvent set into three main disjoint regions as follows:

$$
\rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)=D \cup W \cup U
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
W= & \{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Re}(z)| \geq 5 m / 2,|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\} \\
D= & D(m+i) \cup D(-m+i) \cup D(-m-i) \cup D(m-i) \quad \text { for } \\
& D(m \pm i)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right):\left|\begin{array}{l}
\operatorname{Re}(z-(m \pm i)) \\
\operatorname{Im}(z-(m \pm i))
\end{array}\right| \leq 3 m / 2,\right\} \quad \text { and } \\
& D(-m \pm i)=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right):\left|\begin{array}{l}
\operatorname{Re}(z-(-m \pm i)) \\
|\operatorname{Im}(z-(-m \pm i))| \leq 3 / 2
\end{array}\right|, \quad \text { and }\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
U=\rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \backslash(D \cup W)
$$

See Figure 5.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 5. Partition of the resolvent set of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$ in subdomains for the proof of Theorem 2.5.

We split the proof of Theorem 2.5 according to this partition, deriving suitable estimates for the norm of $Q(z)$ where $z$ is in each of the sub-regions. In this proof, the parameters $c_{j} \equiv c_{j}(m)>0$ only depend on $m$.

Estimates on $D$. The region $D \subset \mathbb{C}$ is the union of four neighbourhoods of singularities of the matrix kernel $\mathcal{R}_{z}$. We will see that these singularities are removable. That is, the matrix norm $\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}$ is bounded uniformly for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, whenever $z \in D( \pm m \pm i)$. We treat each different component separately.

Consider first that $z \in D(m+i)$. From the formulae of $\mu_{z}^{+}, w_{z}^{ \pm}$in (3.3) and $k_{z}$ in (3.19), it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{z \rightarrow m+i} w_{z}^{+}=0, & \lim _{z \rightarrow m+i} w_{z}^{-}=\frac{\sqrt{-1-i m}}{\sqrt{m^{2}+1}} \\
\lim _{z \rightarrow m+i} \frac{\mu_{z}^{+}}{w_{z}^{+}}=2 m, & \lim _{z \rightarrow m+i} k_{z}=-1
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, we gather the following. According to (3.20), for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ such that $x y \leq 0$,

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq \varphi_{z}(0)=\frac{\sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right|} \leq c_{1}
$$

According to (3.21), for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ such that $x \leq 0, y \leq 0$,

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq \sup _{t \leq 0} \varphi_{z}(t) \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right)\left(\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|}\right) \leq c_{2}
$$

According to (3.20), for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ such that $x \geq 0, y \geq 0$,

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq \varphi_{z}(\min \{x, y\})
$$

Now, for all $t \geq 0$, we know that

$$
\varphi_{z}(t)=\frac{\sqrt{1+\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}}}{2}\left(\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|^{2}}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}+1\right|^{2}+\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}-1\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

Because of (5.10), the term that we should take care of is $\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}+1\right|$, as it might potentially exhibit a singularity. We show that this is not the case. Indeed, from (3.19) and (5.10), for $z \in D(m+i)$ and $x \geq 0, y \geq 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}+1\right| & =\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\left|k_{z}\left(e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}-1\right)+1+k_{z}\right| \\
& =\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\left|k_{z}\left(e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}-1\right)+\frac{2 w_{z}^{+}}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}\right| \\
& \leq \frac{\left|\mu_{z}^{+}\right|}{\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|}\left|k_{z}\right||t|+\frac{2}{\left|w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right|} \\
& \leq c_{3}(|t|+1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we have used the inequality $\left|e^{-z}-1\right| \leq|z|$ for $\operatorname{Re} z \geq 0$. Thus, for all $z \in D(m+i)$ and $x \geq 0, y \geq 0$, we have

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq \varphi_{z}(\min \{x, y\}) \leq c_{4}\left(1+|\min \{x, y\}|\right) \leq c_{5} \nu_{1}^{\prime}(x)
$$

Finally, by virtue of (5.6), combining the above estimates we obtain,

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq c_{6} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \nu_{1}^{\prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x
$$

for all $z \in D(m+i)$.
Now let $z \in D(m-i)$. We have

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\lim _{z \rightarrow m-i} w_{z}^{-}=0, & \lim _{z \rightarrow m-i} w_{z}^{+}=\frac{\sqrt{-1+i m}}{\sqrt{m^{2}+1}} \\
\lim _{z \rightarrow m-i} \frac{\mu_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{-}}=2 m, & \lim _{z \rightarrow m-i} k_{z}=1
\end{array}
$$

By means of an identical proof to the one given in the previous region, we can show that if $x y \leq 0$ then (5.11) holds true and if $x \geq 0, y \geq 0$ then (5.12) holds true. We omit the details of that. Moreover, in the case $x \leq 0$ and $y \leq 0$, the term $\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{-}\right|}\left|k_{z} e^{2 \mu_{z}^{-} t}-1\right|$ is bounded by $c_{7}(|t|+1)$. Thus, we gather that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} & \leq \varphi_{z}(\max \{x, y\}) \leq c_{8}(1+|\max \{x, y\}|) \\
& \leq c_{9}\left(1+\min \{|x|,|y|\}\right) \leq c_{10} \nu_{1}^{\prime}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, by virtue of (5.6), we also obtain the estimate (5.14) for all $z \in D(m-i)$, perhaps with a larger constant $c_{6}$.

Now, let $z \in D(-m+i)$. Then,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\lim _{z \rightarrow-m+i} w_{z}^{+}=\infty, & \lim _{z \rightarrow-m+i} w_{z}^{-}=\sqrt{-1-i m} \\
\lim _{z \rightarrow-m+i} \mu_{z}^{+} w_{z}^{+}=2 m, & \lim _{z \rightarrow-m+i} k_{z}=1
\end{array}
$$

We obtain the same estimates as (5.11) for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ satisfying $x y \leq 0$ and (5.12) for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ satisfying $x \leq 0, y \leq 0$, by writing

$$
\frac{\sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|w_{x}^{+}+w_{x}^{-}\right|}=\frac{\sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}}+1\right)\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|1+\frac{w_{x}^{-}}{w_{x}^{+}}\right|}
$$

On the other hand, whenever $x \geq 0, y \geq 0$, we invoke the same estimate $\left|\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{C^{2 \times 2}} \leq \varphi_{z}(\min \{x, y\})$ as on $D(m+i)$, in which, we rewrite

$$
\varphi_{z}(t)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1+\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}}{\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}+1\right|^{2}+\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}-1\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

It is readily seen that, for all $t \geq 0$ and $z \in D(-m+i)$,

$$
\frac{1+\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}}{\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}+1\right|^{2}+\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}t}-1\right|^{2} \leq c_{11}
$$

For the remain term $\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+} t}-1\right|^{2}$, note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|w_{z}^{+}\right|\left|k_{z} e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+} t}-1\right| & =\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|\left|k_{z}\left(e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}} t-1\right)+k_{z}-1\right| \\
& =\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|\left|k_{z}\left(e^{-2 \mu_{z}^{+}} t-1\right)-\frac{2 w_{z}^{-}}{w_{x}^{+}+w_{x}^{-}}\right| \\
& \leq\left|\mu_{z}^{+} w_{z}^{+}\right|\left|k_{z}\right||t|+\frac{2\left|w_{x}^{-}\right|}{\left|1+\frac{w_{x}^{-}}{w_{x}^{+}}\right|} \\
& \leq c_{12}(|t|+1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the estimate (5.13) is valid for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ such that $x \geq 0, y \geq 0$, also whenever $z \in D(-m+i)$. Hence, combining the estimates, once again we gather that (5.14) also holds true for all $z \in D(-m+i)$.

Finally, the case $z \in D(-m-i)$ is similar to the case $z \in D(-m+i)$, so we omit further details. Hence, we then gather that the upper bound,

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq c_{13}(m)\|V\|_{L^{1}\left(\mathrm{~d} \nu_{1}\right)}
$$

is valid for all $z \in D$.
Estimate on $U=\mathbb{C} \backslash \overline{(D \cup W)}$. Split $\bar{U}=U^{+} \cup U^{-}$for

$$
U^{ \pm}=\{z \in \bar{U}: \pm \operatorname{Im} z>0\}
$$

Then, according to (3.3) and (3.19),

$$
\lim _{z \in U^{ \pm}} w_{z}^{ \pm}=-i, \quad \lim _{z \in U^{-}} w_{z}^{ \pm}=i \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{z \in \bar{U}^{-}} k_{z}=0
$$

Hence, by continuity of each of the quantities $\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|,\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|^{-1}$ and $\left|k_{z}\right|$, in $z$, we have that

$$
\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right) \max \left\{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|}\right\} \leq c_{14}(m)
$$

for all $z \in U$. According to (5.6), (3.20) and (3.21), we then gather that

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq c_{14}(m)\|V\|_{L^{1}} \leq c_{14}(m)\|V\|_{L^{1}\left(\mathrm{~d} \nu_{1}\right)}
$$

for all $z \in U$.
Estimate on $W$. By invoking Lemma 4.2, we obtain the following bounds for all $z \in W$;

$$
\frac{\sqrt{\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{+}\right|^{2}\right)\left(1+\left|w_{x}^{-}\right|^{2}\right)}}{\left|w_{x}^{+}+w_{x}^{-}\right|} \leq c_{15}(\operatorname{Re} z)^{2}, \quad\left|w_{x}^{ \pm}\right| \leq c_{16}, \quad\left|w_{x}^{ \pm}\right|^{-1} \leq c_{17}, \quad\left|k_{z}\right| \leq c_{18}(\operatorname{Re} z)^{2}
$$

Then, by virtue of (5.6), (3.20) and (3.21), it follows that

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq c_{19}(m)(\operatorname{Re} z)^{2}\|V\|_{L^{1}}
$$

for all $z \in W$.

Completion of the proof of Theorem 2.5. According to the estimates (5.18) on $D,(5.20)$ on $U$ and (5.21) on $W$, we conclude that there exists a constant $C(m)>0$ such that

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq \frac{1}{C(m)}\|V\|_{L^{1}\left(\operatorname{dr} r_{1}\right)} \quad \text { for all } z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \backslash W
$$

and

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq \frac{1}{C(m)^{2}}(\operatorname{Re} z)^{2}\|V\|_{L^{1}} \quad \text { for all } z \in W
$$

Hence, if we assume $\|V\|_{L^{1}\left(\operatorname{dr} r_{1}\right)}<C(m)$, it follows that $\|Q(z)\|<1$ for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \backslash W$. Hence, -1 is not in the spectrum of $Q(z)$ whenever $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \backslash W$. Theorem A.2, thus implies that all points in $\rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right) \backslash W$ are not eigenvalues of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$. Moreover, the points $z \in W$ satisfying $|\operatorname{Re} z|<C(m) \sqrt{\frac{1}{\|V\|_{L^{1}}}}$ cannot be eigenvalues of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$. Therefore, we deduce that the eigenvalues of $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ (if there is any), should lie in the subset of $W$, corresponding to real part larger than or equal to $C(m) \sqrt{\frac{1}{\|V\|_{L^{1}}}}$. This completes the proof of Theorem 2.5 .
5.3. Step potentials. In this subsection we construct a potential $V \in L^{1}$ such that $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ has infinitely many eigenvalues inside the instability band. We compute explicitly the eigenfunctions by means of an argument similar to the one employed in the proof of Proposition 3.1. We end the subsection by giving the proof of Proposition 2.6.

Set

$$
V_{a, b}(x)=(-i \operatorname{sgn}(x)-b) \chi_{[-a, a]}(x) I
$$

for $a>0$ and $b \in \mathbb{R}$. If $u \neq 0$ is such that $\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V_{a, b}}-z\right) u=0$, then

$$
u(x)= \begin{cases}u_{-}(x) & \text { for } x \in(-\infty,-a) \\ u_{0}(x) & \text { for } x \in[-a, a] \\ u_{+}(x) & \text { for } x \in(a,+\infty)\end{cases}
$$

where $u_{\dagger}$ for $\dagger \in\{-, 0,+\}$, are given similarly as in (3.12), by

$$
u_{\dagger}(x)=\left(e^{\mu_{\dagger}^{+} x} S_{z}^{\dagger}+e^{-\mu_{\dagger}^{+} x} T_{z}^{\dagger}\right)\binom{\alpha_{\dagger}}{\beta_{\dagger}}
$$

Here, $\mu_{z}^{ \pm}$and $w_{z}^{ \pm}$are the same parameters from (3.3) that we considered above,

$$
\mu_{z}^{0}=\sqrt{(m+b+z)(m-b-z)} \quad \text { and } \quad w_{z}^{0}=\frac{\sqrt{m-b-z}}{\sqrt{m+b+z}}
$$

Also

$$
S_{z}^{\dagger}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 1 / w_{1}^{\dagger} \\
w_{z}^{\dagger} & 1
\end{array}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad T_{z}^{\dagger}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & -1 / w_{1}^{\dagger} \\
-w_{z}^{\dagger} & 1
\end{array}\right)
$$

Note that there is a singularity of $u_{0}(x)$ for $z= \pm m-b$, but taking the limits $z \rightarrow \pm m-b$ in (5.24) for $\dagger=0$, we get

$$
u_{0}(x)= \begin{cases}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 2 m x \\
0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\binom{\alpha_{0}}{\beta_{0}}, & \text { if } z=m-b \\ \left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
2 m x & 1
\end{array}\right)\binom{\alpha_{0}}{\beta_{0}}, & \text { if } z=-m-b\end{cases}
$$

We seek for $z \in \mathbb{C}, \alpha_{\dagger}$ and $\beta_{\dagger}$ (non-vanishing simultaneously), such that $u \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, so it becomes a proper eigenfunction.

Since $u$ has to decay at $\pm \infty$ and must be continuous at $\pm a$, then

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}
-w_{z}^{-} & 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & w_{z}^{+} & 1 \\
e^{-\mu_{z}^{-} a} & \frac{e^{-\mu_{z}^{-} a}}{w_{z}^{-}} & -\left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}+e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right) & \frac{\left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}-e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right)}{w_{z}^{0}} & 0 & 0 \\
w_{z}^{-} e^{-\mu_{z}^{-} a} & e^{-\mu_{z}^{-} a} & w_{z}^{0}\left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}-e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right) & -\left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}+e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right) & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}+e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right) & \frac{\left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}-e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right)}{w_{z}^{0}} & -e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} a} & \frac{e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} a}}{w_{z}^{+}} \\
0 & 0 & w_{z}^{0}\left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}-e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right) & \left(e^{\mu_{z}^{0} a}+e^{-\mu_{z}^{0} a}\right) & w_{z}^{+} e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} a} & -e^{-\mu_{z}^{+} a}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\alpha_{-} \\
\beta_{-} \\
\alpha_{0} \\
\beta_{0} \\
\alpha_{+} \\
\beta_{+}
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

The determinant of the matrix vanishes, if and only if,

$$
e^{4 a \mu_{z}^{0}}\left(w_{z}^{0}+w_{z}^{+}\right)\left(w_{z}^{0}+w_{z}^{-}\right)=\left(w_{z}^{0}-w_{z}^{+}\right)\left(w_{z}^{0}-w_{z}^{-}\right)
$$

for eigenvalues $z \neq \pm m-b$ such that

$$
z \notin\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m,|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\}
$$

And it vanishes for $z= \pm m-b$, if and only if

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
w_{m-b}^{+} + w_{m-b}^{-}+4 a m w_{m-b}^{+} w_{m-b}^{-}=0 & \text { when } z=m-b \text { and } \\
w_{-m-b}^{+} + w_{-m-b}^{-}+4 a m=0 & \text { when } z=-m-b .
\end{array}
$$

Note that, no points in $\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Re} z| \geq m,|\operatorname{Im} z|=1\}$ can be an eigenvalue.
Proof of Proposition 2.6. Let $m=0$. Then, directly from the definition it follows that $w_{z}^{0}$ takes one of two values, $\pm i$, depending on the location of $z \in \mathbb{C} \backslash\{ \pm m-b\}$. Moreover, substitution shows that, $|\operatorname{Im} z|<1$, iff $w_{z}^{+}=i$ and $w_{z}^{-}=-i$. Also, we directly see that $z=m-b$ or $z=-m-b$ are eigenvalues, if $|\operatorname{Im} b|<1$. This gives the first conclusion of Proposition 2.6.

Let $m>0$. We show the existence of infinitely many large real eigenvalues. Since, $\left(w_{z}^{0}+w_{z}^{+}\right)\left(w_{z}^{0}+w_{z}^{-}\right) \neq 0$ whenever $z \in \mathbb{R}$, then (5.25) reduces to

$$
e^{i 4 a \sqrt{(z+b)^{2}-m^{2}}}=\frac{\left(w_{z}^{0}-w_{z}^{+}\right)\left(w_{z}^{0}-w_{z}^{-}\right)}{\left(w_{z}^{0}+w_{z}^{+}\right)\left(w_{z}^{0}+w_{z}^{-}\right)}
$$

Now, $\cot (w)=i \frac{e^{i 2 w}-1}{e^{i 2 w}+1}$ for $w \in \mathbb{R}$ and note that $w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-} \neq 0$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$. Thus, we can rewrite this equation as

$$
\cot \left(2 a \sqrt{(z+b)^{2}-m^{2}}\right)=-i \frac{\left(w_{z}^{0}\right)^{2}+w_{z}^{+} w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{0}\left(w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right)}
$$

The right-hand side of this expression is real for real $z$ with sufficiently large modulus. Indeed,

$$
-i \frac{\left(w_{z}^{0}\right)^{2}+w_{z}^{+} w_{z}^{-}}{w_{z}^{0}\left(w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}\right)}= \begin{cases}S(z) & \text { if } z>m-b \\ -S(z) & \text { if } z<-m-b\end{cases}
$$

where

$$
S(z)=\sqrt{\frac{z+m+b}{z-m+b}} \frac{(z-m+b) \sqrt{(z+m)^{2}+1}-(z+m+b) \sqrt{(z-m)^{2}+1}}{2(z+m+b) \operatorname{Re}(\sqrt{z+m+i \sqrt{m+i}-z})}
$$

Since,

$$
\lim _{z \rightarrow+\infty} S(z)=\lim _{z \rightarrow-\infty} S(z)=b
$$

by periodicity, we have infinitely many positive and negative solutions. This is the second statement in Proposition 2.6, and completes its proof.
5.4. The weakly coupled model. At the end of this subsection we give the proof of Theorem 2.7, about localisation of the discrete spectrum for a potential of the form $\epsilon V$ in the asymptotic regime $|\epsilon| \rightarrow 0$, where $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} ; \mathrm{d} \nu_{1}\right)$ satisfies additional hypotheses.

Recall (2.9),

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{dis}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right) \subseteq\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1,|\operatorname{Re} z|>\frac{C(m)}{|\epsilon|^{\frac{1}{2}}\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\right\}
$$

Hence, for small enough $|\epsilon|$, the eigenvalues of $\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}$ lie in the instability band

$$
\Sigma=\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1\}
$$

and they escape to infinity in the regime $|\epsilon| \rightarrow 0$ at a rate proportional to $|\epsilon|^{-\frac{1}{2}}$ or faster. We now formulate a more precise statement about this, for $V$ satisfying a faster decay rate at infinity. The next result is a precursor of Theorem 2.7 and it is one of the main contributions of this paper. We recall that the expression of the densities $\nu_{k}^{\prime}$ are given in Section 2 in the paragraph above Theorem 2.7.
Theorem 5.2. Let $m>0$ and let $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} ; \mathrm{d} \nu_{2}\right)$. Let

$$
\Upsilon_{z}=\frac{1}{2\left(4|z|^{2}+m^{2}\right)}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-(2 z+m)^{2} & i\left(4 z^{2}-m^{2}\right) \\
i\left(4 z^{2}-m^{2}\right) & (2 z-m)^{2}
\end{array}\right) \in \mathbb{C}
$$

for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$. Then,

$$
\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{dis}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right) \subset\left\{z \in \mathbb{C}:|\operatorname{Im} z|<1, \frac{4 m}{4|z|^{2}+m^{2}}=W_{z}(\epsilon)\right\}
$$

where

$$
W_{z}(\epsilon)=\epsilon \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-2\left(|z|+i\left(z-\frac{m^{2}}{2 \operatorname{Re} z}\right) x\right)} \langle V(x), \overline{\Upsilon_{z}}\rangle_{\mathrm{F}} \mathrm{~d} x+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)
$$

in the regime $|\epsilon| \rightarrow 0$.

The verification of the validity of this statement occupies most of this subsection. The explicit dependence on $z$ of $W_{z}(\epsilon)$ and the constant in the limit, will be established below. The proof of (5.28) will invoke Theorem A. 2 once again. Note that the Birman-Schwinger operator associated to $e V$ is $\epsilon Q(z)$. We test whether $z \in \Sigma$ does not belong to $\operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, e V}\right)$, by testing whether $-1 \notin \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}(\epsilon Q(z))$. However, for this we will not appeal directly to estimates for the norm $\|\epsilon Q(z)\|$ as we did in Subsection 5.2. Instead, we will find a criterion, involving $W_{z}(\epsilon)$, to test whether the operator $\epsilon Q(z)+1$ is bijective. Since $Q(z)$ is compact (see the paragraph above Remark 5.1), this is a test on whether $-1 \notin \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}(\epsilon Q(z))$.

The position of the discrete spectrum is associated with sub-regions of $\Sigma$ where the norm of the resolvent is singular. In Subsection 4.2, we isolated the singular part of the unperturbed kernel through the term $\mathcal{R}_{1, z}$. Since the latter still carries the leading order information about the singularities of the perturbed kernel (under small enough perturbations), we now consider a decomposition of the kernel of the integral operator associated to $Q(z)$ that takes the singular contribution of $\mathcal{R}_{1, z}$ into account. For this we proceed as follows.

Let

$$
Q(z)=L(z)+M(z)
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
L(z) f(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} A(x) \mathcal{L}_{z}(x, y) B(y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y, \quad \mathcal{L}_{z}(x, y)=e^{-\eta_{z}(x)-\eta_{z}(y)} U_{z} \\
\eta_{z}(w)=i\left(z-\frac{m^{2}}{2 \operatorname{Re} z}\right) w+|w| \quad \text { and } \quad U_{z}=\frac{1}{8 m}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-(2 z+m)^{2} & i\left(4 z^{2}-m^{2}\right) \\
i\left(4 z^{2}-m^{2}\right) & (2 z-m)^{2}
\end{array}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Then, as we shall see below, $L(z)$ is a rank-one operator for all $z \in \Sigma$ and it carries the leading order contribution of the norm of $Q(z)$ in the asymptotic regime $|\operatorname{Re} z| \rightarrow \infty$. Notably, the kernel $\mathcal{L}_{z}$ encodes the contribution of the singular part of $\mathcal{R}_{1, z}$ in this regime, while $\|M(z)\|$ is uniformly bounded with respect to $z$. Before proving all this, we motivate this decomposition and determine the asymptotic coefficients of the different terms involved in the argument. Recall the notation $z=\tau+i \delta$ for $\tau, \delta \in \mathbb{R}$ with $|\delta|<1$.

On the one hand, we note that the expression of the powers $\eta_{z}(w)$, is motivated by the fact that

$$
-\eta_{z}(w)= \begin{cases}\eta_{z}^{-} w & \text { if } w \leq 0 \\ -\eta_{z}^{+} w & \text { if } w \geq 0\end{cases} \quad \eta_{z}^{-}=(1+\delta)-i\left(\tau-\frac{m^{2}}{2 \tau}\right), \quad \eta_{z}^{+}=(1-\delta)+i\left(\tau-\frac{m^{2}}{2 \tau}\right)
$$

where $\eta_{z}^{ \pm}$are the leading order coefficients in the expansion of the terms $\mu_{z}^{ \pm}$:

$$
\mu_{z}^{ \pm}=\eta_{z}^{ \pm}+\frac{m^{2}(1 \mp \delta)}{2 \tau^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{|\tau|^{3}}\right)
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow+\infty$. See Lemma 4.2 and Table 1.
On the other hand, the expression of the matrix $U_{z}$, has a more involved motivation which is given after the following lemma.

Lemma 5.3. Let the matrices appearing in the expression of the kernel $\mathcal{R}_{1, z}$ in (4.5) be $N_{j, z}$, as defined at the beginning of Subsection 3.1. Let

$$
U_{r+i \delta}^{0}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-\frac{1}{2 m} \tau^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \delta}{m}\right) \tau & \frac{1}{2 m} \tau^{2}-\frac{\delta}{m} \tau \\
\frac{1}{2 m} \tau^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{i \delta}{m}\right) \tau
\end{array}\right)
$$

Then, $N_{j, z}=U_{z}^{0}+\widehat{N}_{j, z}$ where

$$
\left|\widehat{N}_{j, \tau+i \delta}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}=\mathcal{O}(1)
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow \infty$ for all $j \in\{1,3,4,7,8,10\}$.
Proof. By writing

$$
\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}=\frac{-i}{4 m}\left[(m+i+z) \mu_{z}^{+}-(m-i+z) \mu_{z}^{-}\right]
$$

we get that

$$
\frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}+w_{z}^{-}}=\frac{1}{2 m} \tau^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \delta}{m}\right) \tau+\left(\frac{1-\delta^{2}}{2 m}-\frac{m}{4}+\frac{i \delta}{2}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\tau}\right)
$$

as $|\tau| \rightarrow 0$. The claimed asymptotic formula is achieved by substituting the expansions of $w_{z}^{ \pm}, \frac{1}{w_{z}^{+}}$and this expression, into the formulas of the different $N_{j, z}$. See Lemma 4.2.

Now we return to the motivation for the expression of $U_{z}$. We pick the latter, so that it approximates all the matrices $N_{j, z}$ up to order $\tau$. Indeed, writing $U_{z}$ in terms of $\tau$ and $\delta$, gives

$$
U_{\tau+i \delta}=U_{\tau+i \delta}^{0}+U_{\delta}^{1}
$$

for $U_{z}^{0}$ as in Lemma 5.3 and

$$
U_{\delta}^{1}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\delta^{2}}{2 m}-\frac{m}{8}-\frac{i \delta}{2} & -i\left(\frac{\delta^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{m}{8}\right) \\
-i\left(\frac{\delta^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{m}{8}\right) & -\frac{\delta^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{m}{8}-\frac{i \delta}{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Note that for all $z \in \Sigma$, $\operatorname{det} U_{z}=0$ and $U_{z}$ is of rank one. Then, the matrix norm of $U_{z}$ can be computed explicitly,

$$
\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}=\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{|z|^{2}}{m}+\frac{m}{4}
$$

We are now ready to formulate the crucial step in the proof of Theorem 5.2.
Lemma 5.4. Let $V \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}, \mathrm{~d} \nu_{2}\right)$. For $A(x)$ and $B(y)$ as in (5.1), let $L(z)$ be the integral operator (5.29) and let $M(z)=Q(z)-L(z)$. Let $\Upsilon_{z}=\frac{1}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}} U_{z}$ be as in (5.27). Then

$$
L(z) f=\left(\frac{|z|^{2}}{m}+\frac{m}{4}\right)\left\langle f, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle \phi_{z}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi_{z}(w)= \begin{cases}e^{-\eta_{z}(w)} B(w)^{T}\left(\frac{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11}}{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{12}}\right) & \text { if } z \neq \frac{-m}{2} \\
e^{-\eta_{z}(w)} B(w)^{T}\left(\frac{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{21}}{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{22}}\right) & \text { if } z=\frac{-m}{2}\end{cases} \\
& \phi_{z}(w)= \begin{cases}e^{-\eta_{z}(w)} A(w)\left(\frac{1}{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{21} /\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11}}\right) & \text { if } z \neq \frac{-m}{2} \\
e^{-\eta_{z}(w)} A(w)\left(\frac{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{12} /\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{22}}{1}\right) & \text { if } z=\frac{-m}{2}\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, there exists a constant $C(m)>0$ such that $\left\|M_{z}\right\| \leq C(m)$ for all $z \in \Sigma$.
Proof. Assume first that $z \neq \frac{-m}{2}$. Since $U_{z}$ is singular and non-zero, then

$$
U_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
\left(U_{z}\right)_{21} /\left(U_{z}\right)_{11}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
\left(U_{z}\right)_{11} & \left(U_{z}\right)_{12}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Thus, we can rewrite the action of the operator $L_{z}$ in the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
L_{z} f(x) & =\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-\eta_{z}(x)-\eta_{z}(y)} A(x)\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{21} /\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11}
\end{array}\right)\left(\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11} \quad\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{12}\right) B(y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y \\
& =\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-\eta_{z}(y)}\left(\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11} \quad\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{12}\right) B(y) f(y) \mathrm{d} y\right) \phi_{z}(x) \\
& =\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left\langle f(y), \overline{\psi_{z}(y)}\right\rangle_{\mathbb{C}^{2}} \mathrm{~d} y\right) \phi_{z}(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

This is the claimed expression for the operator $L_{z}$.
Both vector-valued functions $\psi_{z}$ and $\phi_{z}$ belong to $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$ because $\operatorname{Re} \eta_{z}^{ \pm}=1 \mp \delta>0$ and thus, for all $z \in \Sigma \backslash\left\{-\frac{m}{2}\right\}$

$$
\left\|\psi_{z}\right\| \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{1 / 2} \sqrt{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11}^{2}+\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{22}^{2}}, \quad\left\|\phi_{z}\right\| \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{1 / 2} \sqrt{1+\frac{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{21}^{2}}{\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{11}^{2}}}
$$

Therefore, we can conclude that, for all $z \in \Sigma \backslash\left\{-\frac{m}{2}\right\}, L_{z}$ is an operator of rank-one and

$$
\left\|L_{z}\right\|=\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\left\|\psi_{z}\right\|\left\|\phi_{z}\right\| \leq\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\|V\|_{L^{1}}
$$

Now, to achieve the same conclusion for $z=-\frac{m}{2}$, we can just write the matrix $U_{z}$ in different form, as

$$
U_{z}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\left(U_{z}\right)_{12} /\left(U_{z}\right)_{22} \\
1
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
\left(U_{z}\right)_{21} & \left(U_{z}\right)_{22}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and follow the same argument as above.
Next, let us complete the proof of the lemma by showing the validity of the claim made about $M_{z}$. Let

$$
\mathcal{M}_{z}(x, y)=\mathcal{R}_{z}(x, y)-\mathcal{L}_{z}(x, y)
$$

Then,

$$
\mathcal{M}_{z}(x, y)=\left(\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)-\mathcal{L}_{z}(x, y)\right)+\mathcal{R}_{2, z}(x, y)
$$

By virtue of (4.6), (4.7) and Lemma 4.2, it follows that there exists a constant $c_{1}>0$ such that

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{2, z}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq c_{1}
$$

for all $|\tau| \geq 1$.
Let us now show that the difference of $\mathcal{R}_{1, z}-\mathcal{L}_{z}$ is also uniformly bounded. Let

$$
\mu_{z}(x)= \begin{cases}\mu_{z}^{-} x & \text { if } x \leq 0 \\ -\mu_{z}^{+} x & \text { if } x \geq 0\end{cases}
$$

Then

$$
\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)=N_{j, z} e^{\mu_{z}(x)+\mu_{z}(y)}
$$

for $j$ chosen depending on the signs of $x$ and $y$ as in (4.5). For all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, write

$$
\Lambda_{z}(x, y)=\mu_{z}(x)+\eta_{z}(x)+\mu_{z}(y)+\eta_{z}(y)
$$

Then,

$$
\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)-\mathcal{L}_{z}(x, y)=U_{z}\left(e^{\Lambda_{z}(x, y)}-1\right) e^{-\eta_{z}(x)-\eta_{z}(y)}+\left(N_{j, z}-U_{z}\right) e^{\mu_{z}(x)+\mu_{z}(y)}
$$

Since $\operatorname{Re} \Lambda_{z}(x, y)<0$ for all $(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ and by virtue of (5.30), considering $|\tau|$ sufficiently large so that $\operatorname{Re}\left(\mu_{z}^{+}+\eta_{z}^{+}\right)>0$ and $\operatorname{Re}\left(\mu_{z}^{-}+\eta_{z}^{-}\right)>0$, gives

$$
\left|e^{\Lambda_{z}(x, y)}-1\right| \leq\left|\Lambda_{z}(x, y)\right| \leq \frac{c_{2}}{\tau^{2}}(|x|+|y|)
$$

Therefore, since $\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}(x)<0$ and $\operatorname{Re} \eta_{z}(x)>0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, according to Lemma 5.3 and to (5.31), we have

$$
\left|\mathcal{R}_{1, z}(x, y)-\mathcal{L}_{z}(x, y)\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}\left|e^{\Lambda_{z}(x, y)}-1\right|+\left|N_{j, z}-U_{z}\right|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \leq c_{3}(|x|+|y|+1)
$$

for all $|\tau| \geq \tau_{0}$.
From (5.36) and (5.37) it follows that, by taking the Hilbert-Schmidt norm in the decomposition (5.35),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|M(z)\|^{2} & \leq c_{4} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}}(1+|x|+|y|)^{2}|V(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \mathrm{~d} x \mathrm{~d} y \\
& \leq c_{5}\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} \nu_{2}^{\prime}}(x) \mathrm{d} x\right)\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}|V(y)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2} \nu_{2}^{\prime}}(y) \mathrm{d} y\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the right-hand side is finite and independent of $z$, for all $|\tau| \geq \tau_{0}$. On the other hand, according to (5.34) for $L(z)$, and (5.22)-(5.23) for $Q(z)$, the triangle inequality yields,

$$
\|M(z)\| \leq\|Q(z)\|+\|L(z)\| \leq c_{6} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|V(x)|_{\mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}} \nu_{1}^{\prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x<\infty
$$

for all $|\tau| \leq \tau_{0}$, where the right-hand side is also independent of $z$. This completes the proof of the lemma.

With this lemma at hand, we complete the proof of Theorem 5.2 as follows.
Proof of Theorem 5.2. Since $\|M(z)\|$ is uniformly bounded for all $z \in \Sigma$, the operator $I+\epsilon M(z)$ is invertible whenever

$$
0<\epsilon<\frac{1}{C(m)}
$$

Assume this from now on. Then, since

$$
I+\epsilon Q(z)=I+\epsilon(L(z)+M(z))=(I+\epsilon M(z))\left(I+\epsilon(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} L(z)\right)
$$

we have

$$
z \in \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right) \Longleftrightarrow-1 \in \operatorname{Spec}(\epsilon(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} L(z))
$$

By virtue of Lemma 5.4, $L(z)$ is a rank-one operator. Therefore, $\epsilon(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} L(z)$ is also a rank-one operator, such that

$$
\epsilon(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} L(z) f=\epsilon\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\left\langle f, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} \phi_{z}
$$

Hence, $\epsilon(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} L(z)$, being a compact operator on the infinite-dimension Hilbert space $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2}\right)$, has spectrum

$$
\operatorname{Spec}\left(\epsilon(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} L(z)\right)=\left\{0, \epsilon\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\left\langle(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} \phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle\right\}
$$

Thus, from (5.38) and by writing $\left(I+\epsilon M(z)\right)^{-1}=I-\epsilon M(z)(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1}$, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
z \in \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right) & \Longleftrightarrow-1=\epsilon\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}\left\langle\left(I+\epsilon M(z)\right)^{-1} \phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \frac{1}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}}=-\epsilon\left\langle\phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle+\epsilon^{2}\left\langle M(z)(I+\epsilon M(z))^{-1} \phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \frac{4 m}{4|z|^{2}+m^{2}}=W_{z}(\epsilon)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $W_{z}(\epsilon)$ is the right-hand side of the second line in this expression. This is (5.28).
We complete the proof by confirming the claimed asymptotic formula for $W_{z}(\epsilon)$. Notice that,

$$
\left\langle\phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle=-\int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-2 \eta_{\epsilon}(x)}\left\langle V(x), \overline{\Upsilon_{z}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{F}} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

because $V(x)=B(x) A(x)$ and $\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{12}=\left(\Upsilon_{z}\right)_{21}$. Now,

$$
\left|\left\langle M(z)\left(I+\epsilon M(z)\right)^{-1} \phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle\right| \leq \frac{\|M(z)\|}{1-\epsilon\|M(z)\|}\left\|\phi_{z}\right\|\left\|\psi_{z}\right\| \leq \frac{\left\|M_{z}\right\|\|V\|_{L^{1}}}{1-\epsilon\left\|M_{z}\right\|} \leq c_{7}
$$

This is a consequence of (5.33) and the fact that $\|M(z)\|$ is uniformly bounded on $\Sigma$, and it completes the proof of the theorem.

Proof of Theorem 2.7. As setting in (5.39), we write

$$
W_{z}(\epsilon)=\epsilon a_{z}+\epsilon^{2} b_{z}(\epsilon)
$$

where $a_{z}=-\left\langle\phi_{z}, \overline{\psi_{z}}\right\rangle$ is independent of $\epsilon$ and $\left|b_{z}(\epsilon)\right| \leq c_{1}$ for all $z \in \Sigma$ and sufficiently small $|\epsilon|$.
We aim to show that there exists a constant $c_{2}>0$ such that

$$
\left|a_{\tau+i \delta}\right| \leq \frac{c_{2}}{\left|U_{\tau+i \delta}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}}
$$

for all $|\tau| \geq 1$. To establish this, we first use integration by parts twice to obtain the following results:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-2 \eta_{\epsilon}(x)} v(x) \mathrm{d} x= & \left(\frac{1}{4\left(\eta_{\epsilon}^{2}\right)^{2}}-\frac{1}{4\left(\eta_{\epsilon}^{-}\right)^{2}}\right) v^{\prime}(0)-\left(\frac{1}{2 \eta_{\epsilon}^{-}}+\frac{1}{2 \eta_{\epsilon}^{2}}\right) v(0) \\
& +\frac{1}{4\left(\eta_{\epsilon}^{-}\right)^{2}} \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{2 \eta_{\epsilon}^{-} x} v^{\prime \prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x+\frac{1}{4\left(\eta_{\epsilon}^{2}\right)^{2}} \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-2 \eta_{\epsilon}^{+} x} v^{\prime \prime}(x) \mathrm{d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

for any $v \in W^{2,1}(\mathbb{R})$. Now, from the expressions for $\eta_{z}^{ \pm}$, it follows that for suitable constants $c_{k}>0$,

$$
\left|\frac{1}{2 \eta_{\epsilon}^{-}}+\frac{1}{2 \eta_{\epsilon}^{2}}\right|=\frac{1}{\left|\eta_{\epsilon}^{-} \eta_{\epsilon}^{2}\right|} \leq \frac{c_{3}}{\tau^{2}} \leq \frac{c_{4}}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}} \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{1}{\left|\eta_{\epsilon}^{2}\right|^{2}} \leq \frac{c_{5}}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}}
$$

for all $|\tau| \geq 1$. Since the Frobenius norm of $\Upsilon_{z}$ is one, setting $v(x)=\left\langle V(x), \overline{\Upsilon_{z}}\right\rangle_{\mathrm{F}}$ gives

$$
\left|v^{(j)}(x)\right| \leq\left|V^{(j)}(x)\right|_{\mathrm{F}}
$$

for $j \in\{0,1,2\}$ and all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence, according to (5.40), we have that (5.41) is indeed valid under the hypothesis $V \in W^{2,1}\left(\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{C}^{2 \times 2}\right)$.

According to Theorem 5.2, $z$ belongs to $\operatorname{Spec}_{\text {dis }}\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}\right)$ if and only if

$$
\frac{1}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}}=W_{z}(\epsilon)
$$

To satisfy this condition, $z$ must be in $\Sigma$ such that

$$
\left|\frac{1}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}}-\epsilon a_{z}\right|=\epsilon^{2}\left|b_{z}(\epsilon)\right|
$$

Then, $z$ should meet the requirement

$$
\frac{1}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}}\left(1-\epsilon c_{2}\right) \leq \epsilon^{2} c_{1}
$$

Therefore, there must exists a constant $c_{6}>0$ such that

$$
\frac{1}{\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}} \leq c_{6} \epsilon^{2}
$$

for all sufficiently small $|\epsilon|$. Consequently, for $z$ to be an eigenvalue of $\mathscr{L}_{m, \epsilon V}$ when $|\epsilon|$ is small, we require

$$
|\operatorname{Re} z|^{2} \geq c_{7}\left|U_{z}\right|_{\mathrm{F}}>c_{8} \epsilon^{-2}
$$

This condition ensures the validity of Theorem 2.7.

5.5. Proof of Theorem 2.4. Assume that $V$ satisfies the condition H2. According to Proposition 2.3, we know that $Q(z)=\overline{A R_{0}(z) B}$ is well defined for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$. Moreover, by virtue of (5.9),

$$
\|Q(z)\| \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}} \frac{\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right) \max \left\{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|}\right\}}{2}
$$

for all such $z$. Recall the set $U$ defined in Subsection 5.2 and recall that (5.19) is valid for all $z \in U$. Then, for $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<\frac{2}{c_{14}(m)}=: C(m),\|Q(z)\|<1$ and so

$$
\left\|(1+Q(z))^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{C(m)}{C(m)-\|V\|_{L^{1}}}
$$

for all $z \in U$. Now, from (5.4) and (5.5), we have

$$
\max \left\{\left\|\overline{R_{0}(z) B}\right\|,\left\|A R_{0}(z)\right\|\right\} \leq\|V\|_{L^{1}}^{\frac{1}{2}} \frac{\left(\left|k_{z}\right|+1\right) \max \left\{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|+\frac{1}{\left|w_{z}^{ \pm}\right|}\right\}}{2\left(\min \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}}
$$

for all $z \in \rho\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}\right)$.
Consider the minimum in the denominator of the right-hand side. Since $\operatorname{Re} \sqrt{\gamma}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sqrt{|\gamma|+\operatorname{Re} \gamma}$, we have that

$$
\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sqrt{\sqrt{\left(\tau^{2}-m^{2}-(1 \mp \delta)^{2}\right)^{2}+4(1 \mp \delta)^{2} \tau^{2}}+m^{2}+(1 \mp \delta)^{2}-\tau^{2}}
$$

Hence, since $\tau^{2} \geq \tau^{2}-m^{2}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\tau^{2}-m^{2}-(1 \mp \delta)^{2}\right)^{2}+4(1 \mp \delta)^{2} \tau^{2} & \geq\left(\tau^{2}-m^{2}-(1 \mp \delta)^{2}\right)^{2}+4(1 \mp \delta)^{2}\left(\tau^{2}-m^{2}\right) \\
& =\left(\tau^{2}-m^{2}+(1 \mp \delta)^{2}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$
