Thus, $\operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm} \geq|1 \mp \delta|$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$ and so $\min \operatorname{Re} \mu_{z}^{ \pm} \geq|\delta|-1$ for all $|\delta|>1$.
Gathering the estimates above, we then have that, if $\|V\|_{L^{1}} \leq C(m)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}-z\right)^{-1}-\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| & \leq\left\|\overline{R_{0}(z) B}\right\|\left\|\left(I+Q(z)\right)^{-1}\right\|\left\|A R_{0}(z)\right\| \\
& \leq \frac{\|V\|_{L^{1}}}{(\|\operatorname{Im} z|-1) C(m)\left(C(m)-\|V\|_{L^{1}}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $z \in U$. Moreover, since $U$ lies outside the numerical range of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$, then

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq \frac{1}{|\operatorname{Im} z|-1}
$$

for all $z \in U$. Therefore, according to the triangle inequality, whenever $\|V\|_{L^{1}}<C(m)$, we have that

$$
\left\|\left(\mathscr{L}_{m, V}-z\right)^{-1}\right\| \leq\left(1+\frac{\|V\|_{L^{1}}}{C(m)\left(C(m)-\|V\|_{L^{1}}\right)}\right) \frac{1}{|\operatorname{Im} z|-1}
$$

for all $z \in U$. This gives the claim made in Theorem 2.4.

# Appendix A. Abstract Birman-Schwinger principle 

In order to characterise the domain of the operator $\mathscr{L}_{m, V}$ in terms of the resolvent of $\mathscr{L}_{m}$, we follows the classical approach of [17], which was extended to the non-selfadjoint regime in [13]. We include precise details of this construction in this appendix, as the abstract framework might be applicable to other families of operators related to perturbations of $\mathscr{D}_{m}$.

Let $\mathcal{H}$ and $\mathcal{K}$ be two Hilbert spaces. Let $\operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}\right) \subset \mathcal{H}, \operatorname{Dom}(A) \subset \mathcal{H}$ and $\operatorname{Dom}(B) \subset \mathcal{K}$ be three dense subspaces. Let

$$
H_{0}: \operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{H}, \quad A: \operatorname{Dom}(A) \longrightarrow \mathcal{K} \quad \text { and } \quad B: \operatorname{Dom}(B) \longrightarrow \mathcal{H}
$$

be three closed operators, such that $H_{0}$ has a non-empty resolvent set. Let

$$
R_{0}(z)=\left(H_{0}-z I_{\mathcal{H}}\right)^{-1}, \quad z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right)
$$

We consider the following hypotheses.
(B1) For some (and hence all) $z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right)$,

- the operator $R_{0}(z) B$ is closable, the closure $\overline{R_{0}(z) B}: \mathcal{K} \longrightarrow \mathcal{H}$ is bounded,
- and the operator $A R_{0}(z): \mathcal{H} \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}$ is bounded.
(B2) For some (and hence all) $z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right)$, the operator $A R_{0}(z) B$ has a bounded closure,

$$
Q(z)=\overline{A R_{0}(z) B}: \mathcal{K} \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}
$$

(B3) The set

$$
\mathrm{R}=\left\{z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right):-1 \in \rho(Q(z))\right\}
$$

is non-empty.
For all $z \in \mathrm{R}$, we let

$$
R(z)=R_{0}(z)-\overline{R_{0}(z) B}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}(z): \mathcal{H} \longrightarrow \mathcal{H}
$$

Theorem A.1. Assume that the closed operators $H_{0}, A$ and $B$ are related in the above manner, and that (B1)-(B3) hold true. Then, there exists a closed densely defined extension ${ }^{4}$

$$
H \supseteq H_{0}+B A: \operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}\right) \cap \operatorname{Dom}(B A) \longrightarrow \mathcal{H}
$$

whose resolvent is given by

$$
\left(H-z I_{\mathcal{H}}\right)^{-1}=R(z), \quad \text { for all } z \in \mathrm{R}
$$

The conclusion of Theorem A. 1 can be found in [13, Thm. 2.3], assuming the slightly more stringent conditions [13, Hyp. 2.1 (i)];

$$
\operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}\right) \subset \operatorname{Dom}(A) \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}^{*}\right) \subset \operatorname{Dom}\left(B^{*}\right)
$$

In this appendix we show that the assumption (B1) also ensures the claimed conclusion.
Proof. We split the proof into four steps.
Step 1. Let $z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right)$, then the product $A R_{0}(z) B$ is always closable. Indeed, we claim that $A R_{0}(z) B$ is densely defined and its adjoint is also densely defined, see [25, Thm. 1.8 (i)]. The former is an immediate consequence of (B1), so that

$$
\operatorname{Dom}\left(A R_{0}(z) B\right)=\operatorname{Dom}(B)
$$

For the latter, according to [25, Prop. 1.7], we know that

$$
\left(A R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*} \supset\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*} A^{*}
$$

Then, by virtue of [25, Thm. 1.8 (ii)], $\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*}=\left(\overline{R_{0}(z) B}\right)^{*}$, so by (B1) we have

$$
\operatorname{Dom}\left(\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*} A^{*}\right)=\operatorname{Dom}\left(A^{*}\right)
$$

Since $A$ is closed, $\operatorname{Dom}\left(A^{*}\right)$ and thus $\operatorname{Dom}\left(\left(A R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*}\right)$ are dense in $\mathcal{K}$.
Step 2. Let $z \in \mathrm{R}$. Our second task is to construct a closed densely defined operator, $H(z)$, such that

$$
R(z)=\left(H(z)-z I_{\mathcal{H}}\right)^{-1}
$$

For this purpose, firstly observe that

$$
\overline{R_{0}(z) B}(\mathcal{K}) \subset \operatorname{Dom}(A) \quad \text { and } \quad Q(z)=A \overline{R_{0}(z) B}
$$

Indeed, for $f \in \operatorname{Dom}(B)$ and $g \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(A^{*}\right)$, we have

$$
\left\langle R_{0}(z) B f, A^{*} g\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}}=\left\langle A R_{0}(z) B f, g\right\rangle_{\mathcal{K}}=\langle Q(z) f, g\rangle_{\mathcal{K}}
$$

Here the second equality is valid as a consequence of (A.2). Thus, the continuity of $\overline{R_{0}(z) B}$ and $Q(z)$, combined with the density of $\operatorname{Dom}(B)$ in $\mathcal{K}$, imply

$$
\left\langle\overline{R_{0}(z) B} f, A^{*} g\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}}=\langle Q(z) f, g\rangle_{\mathcal{K}}
$$

for all $f \in \mathcal{K}$ and $g \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(A^{*}\right)$. This gives (A.4).
Now, multiplying $R(z)$ by $A$ on the left, according to (A.1) and (A.4), we get that

$$
A R(z)=A R_{0}(z)-Q(z)\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}(z)=\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}(z)
$$

This yields the following. If $R(z) f=0$, where $f \in \mathcal{H}$, then $A R_{0}(z) f=0$. Hence, by (A.1), $R_{0}(z) f=0$ and so $f=0$. That is, $R(z)$ is necessarily injective.

The adjoint of $R(z)$ is given by

$$
R(z)^{*}=R_{0}(z)^{*}-\left(A R_{0}(z)\right)^{*}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)^{*}\right)^{-1}\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*}
$$

By virtue of [25, Thm. 1.8 (ii) \& Prop. 1.7 (ii)], we gather that $Q(z)^{*}=B^{*}\left(A R_{0}(z)\right)^{*}$. In conjunction with (A.5), this yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
B^{*} R(z)^{*} & =\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*}-Q(z)^{*}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)^{*}\right)^{-1}\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*} \\
& =\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)^{*}\right)^{-1}\left(R_{0}(z) B\right)^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ Here $\operatorname{Dom}(B A)=\left\{f \in \operatorname{Dom}(A): A f \in \operatorname{Dom}(B)\right\}$.

Reasoning out as proving the injection of $R(z)$ as above by using (A.5) and (A.6), we obtain

$$
\operatorname{Ker}\left(R(z)^{*}\right)=\{0\}
$$

Hence $R(z)(\mathcal{K})$ is dense in $\mathcal{H}$.
For each $z \in \mathrm{R}$, we can then set $H(z)=R(z)^{-1}+z I_{\mathcal{H}}$. By construction, $H(z)$ is a closed densely defined operator satisfying (A.3). Note that $H(z)$ is ensured to be closed as a consequence of [25, Thm. 1.8 (vi)].
Step 3. We now show that the operator $H(z)$ from the previous step, does not depend on $z \in \mathrm{R}$.
Let $z_{1}, z_{2} \in \mathrm{R}$. Then, $H\left(z_{j}\right)$ are such that

$$
R\left(z_{j}\right)=\left(H\left(z_{j}\right)-z_{j} I_{\mathcal{H}}\right)^{-1}
$$

We claim that $H\left(z_{1}\right)=H\left(z_{2}\right)$. To prove this claim, note that $R(z)$ satisfies the resolvent identity

$$
R\left(z_{1}\right)-R\left(z_{2}\right)=\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right) R\left(z_{2}\right) R\left(z_{1}\right)
$$

Indeed, by (A.1), (A.8) and (A.9), it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right) R\left(z_{2}\right) R\left(z_{1}\right)= & R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)-R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)-\left[\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)} \bar{B}-\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}\right]\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{1}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) \\
& -\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{2}\right)\right)^{-1} A\left[R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)-R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)\right] \\
& +\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{2}\right)\right)^{-1}\left[Q\left(z_{1}\right)-Q\left(z_{2}\right)\right]\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{1}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) \\
= & R\left(z_{1}\right)-R\left(z_{2}\right)+\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}\left[\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{1}\right)\right)^{-1}-\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{2}\right)\right)^{-1}\right] A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) \\
& +\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{2}\right)\right)^{-1}\left[Q\left(z_{1}\right)-Q\left(z_{2}\right)\right]\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{1}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) \\
= & R\left(z_{1}\right)-R\left(z_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By multiplying both sides of (A.7) by $H\left(z_{2}\right)-z_{2} I_{\mathcal{H}}$ on the left, we get

$$
\left(H\left(z_{2}\right)-z_{2} I_{\mathcal{H}}\right) R\left(z_{1}\right)-I_{H}=\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right) R\left(z_{1}\right)
$$

This is equivalent to

$$
\left(H\left(z_{2}\right)-z_{1} I_{\mathcal{H}}\right) R\left(z_{1}\right)=I_{\mathcal{H}}
$$

Multiplying this identity by $H\left(z_{1}\right)-z_{1} I_{\mathcal{H}}$ on the right, ensures that $H\left(z_{1}\right)=H\left(z_{2}\right)$ as claimed above. We can therefore write $H=H(z)$.
Step 4. We complete the proof by showing that $H$ is an extension of the operator $H_{0}+B A$.
Let $z \in \mathrm{R}$ and let $f \in \operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}+B A\right)=\operatorname{Dom}\left(H_{0}\right) \cap \operatorname{Dom}(B A)$. We set $g=\left(H_{0}-z I_{\mathcal{H}}\right) f$. It follows from (A.1) and (A.6) that

$$
R(z)=R_{0}(z)-\overline{R(z) B} A R_{0}(z)
$$

and thus that $R(z) g=f-R(z) B A f$. This completes the proof of the theorem.
The next comments about the validity of the hypotheses (B1) and (B2), when moving $z$, as now in place. The next observations was used in the step 3 in the proof of Theorem A. 1 and will be useful in the proof of Theorem A.2. Here, $z_{1}, z_{2} \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right)$.

If $A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) \in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})$, then $A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) \in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})$. Indeed, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) & =A\left[R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)+\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)\right] \\
& \supseteq \underbrace{A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)}_{\in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})}+\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) \underbrace{A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)}_{\in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})} \underbrace{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)}_{\in L(\mathcal{H})}
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, since the domain of the right-hand side is total $\mathcal{H}$, we obtain

$$
A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)=A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right)+\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)
$$

Thus, $A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) \in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})$.
If $R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B$ is closable and $\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B} \in L(\mathcal{K}, \mathcal{H})$, then $R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B$ is also closable and $\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B} \in L(\mathcal{K}, \mathcal{H})$. Indeed, since $\operatorname{Dom}\left(R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B\right)=\operatorname{Dom}(B)$ which is densely define, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B\right)^{*} & =\left[R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B+\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right]^{*} \\
& \supseteq\left[R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right]^{*}+\left(\overline{z_{2}}-\overline{z_{1}}\right)\left[R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right]^{*} \\
& =\underbrace{\left(\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}\right)^{*}}_{\in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})}+\left(\overline{z_{2}}-\overline{z_{1}}\right) \underbrace{\left(\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}\right)^{*}}_{\in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})} \underbrace{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)^{*}}_{\in L(\mathcal{H})}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used [25, Prop. 1.6 (vi)] for the inclusion and [25, Prop. 1.7(ii) \& Theo. 1.8 (ii)] for the last equality. Since the domain of the right-hand side is total $\mathcal{H}$, we deduce that

$$
\left(R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B\right)^{*}=\overline{\left(R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right)^{*}}+\left(\overline{z_{2}}-\overline{z_{1}}\right) \overline{\left(R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right)^{*}} R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)^{*} \in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})
$$

Therefore, from [25, Thm. 1.8 (i) \& (ii)], $R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B$ is closable and $\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}=\left(R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B\right)^{* *}$ belongs to $L(\mathcal{K}, \mathcal{H})$, as claimed. Moreover, the following identity holds true,

$$
\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}-\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B}=\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) \overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}
$$

If $\overline{A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B} \in L(\mathcal{K})$, then $\overline{A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B} \in L(\mathcal{K})$. This can be proved in the same manner as above:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B\right)^{*}= & {\left[A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B+\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right]^{*} } \\
\supset & {\left[A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right]^{*}+\left(\overline{z_{2}}-\overline{z_{1}}\right)\left[A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right]^{*} } \\
= & \underbrace{\left(\overline{A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}\right)^{*}}_{\in L(\mathcal{K})}+\left(\overline{z_{2}}-\overline{z_{1}}\right) \underbrace{\left(\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}\right)^{*}}_{\in L(\mathcal{H}, \mathcal{K})} \underbrace{\left(A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)^{*}\right.}_{\in L(\mathcal{K}, \mathcal{H})} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Once again, since the domain of the right-hand side is total $\mathcal{K}$,

$$
\left(A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) B\right)^{*}=\overline{\left(A R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right)^{*}}+\left(\overline{z_{2}}-\overline{z_{1}}\right) \overline{\left(R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B\right)^{*}}\left(A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right)^{*} \in L(\mathcal{K})\right.
$$

and the conclusion follows. Moreover, we get the formula

$$
Q\left(z_{1}\right)-Q\left(z_{2}\right)=\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right) A R_{0}\left(z_{2}\right) \overline{R_{0}\left(z_{1}\right) B}
$$

Theorem A.2. Assume that the closed operators $H_{0}, A$ and $B$ are related in the above manner, and that (B1)-(B3) hold true. Additionally, assume that R has at least two elements. Then, for all $z \in \rho\left(H_{0}\right)$,

$$
z \in \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}(H) \quad \text { if and only if } \quad-1 \in \operatorname{Spec}_{\mathrm{p}}(Q(z))
$$

Proof. We first show that the left-hand side implies the right-hand side. Let $f \in \operatorname{Dom}(H) \backslash\{0\}$ be such that $H f=z f$. Let $z_{0} \in \mathrm{R} \backslash\{z\}$. The equation $H f=z f$ is equivalent to $f=\left(z-z_{0}\right) R\left(z_{0}\right) f$. By virtue of (A.1), the latter happens if and only if

$$
\left(H_{0}-z I_{\mathcal{H}}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) f=-\left(z-z_{0}\right) \overline{R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) B}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) f
$$

By setting $v=\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) f \neq 0$ and applying $\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}(z)$ on both sides, we obtain

$$
v=-\left(z-z_{0}\right)\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}(z) \overline{R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) B} v
$$

Then, according to (A.9),

$$
v=\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1}\left(Q\left(z_{0}\right)-Q(z)\right) v \quad \Longleftrightarrow \quad Q(z) v=-v
$$

In other words, -1 is the eigenvalue of $Q(z)$ with the eigenfunction $v$, as the right-hand side of the conclusion states.

We now show the converse. Assume that $Q(z) v=-v$ for some $v \in \mathcal{K} \backslash\{0\}$. Take $z_{0} \in \mathrm{R} \backslash\{z\}$ and write

$$
\begin{aligned}
v & =v-\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1}\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q(z)\right) v=\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1}\left(Q\left(z_{0}\right)-Q(z)\right) v \\
& =\left(z_{0}-z\right)\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) \overline{R_{0}(z) B} v
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, in the last step, we applied (A.9). By setting $f=-\overline{R_{0}(z) B} v \neq 0$, we get

$$
v=\left(z-z_{0}\right)\left(I_{\mathcal{K}}+Q\left(z_{0}\right)\right)^{-1} A R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) f
$$

Then, applying $\overline{R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) B}$ on both sides, and using (A.8) and (A.1), we gather that

$$
-f+\left(z-z_{0}\right) R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right) f=\left(z-z_{0}\right)\left(R_{0}\left(z_{0}\right)-R\left(z_{0}\right)\right) f
$$

This is equivalent to $\left(z-z_{0}\right)\left(H-z_{0} I_{\mathcal{H}}\right)^{-1} f=f$ and thus, $f \in \operatorname{Dom}(H)$ and $H f=z f$.

abstract:
In this paper we present a complete spectral analysis of Dirac operators with
non-Hermitian matrix potentials of the form $i\operatorname{sgn}(x)+V(x)$ where
$V\in L^1$. For $V=0$ we compute explicitly the matrix Green function. This
allows us to determine the spectrum, which is purely essential, and its
different types. It also allows us to find sharp enclosures for the
pseudospectrum and its complement, in all parts of the complex plane. Notably,
this includes the instability region, corresponding to the interior of the band
that forms the numerical range. Then, with the help of a Birman-Schwinger
principle, we establish in precise manner how the spectrum and pseudospectrum
change when $V\not=0$, assuming the hypotheses $\|V\|_{L^1}<1$ or $V\in L^1\cap
L^p$ where $p>1$. We show that the essential spectra remain unchanged and that
the $\varepsilon$-pseudospectrum stays close to the instability region for
small $\varepsilon$. We determine sharp asymptotic for the discrete spectrum,
whenever $V$ satisfies further conditions of decay at infinity. Finally, in one
of our main findings, we give a complete description of the weakly-coupled
model.
